Very cute shop management/dungeon crawler about working your way out of crippling debt - a story I believe many of us can empathize with. I guess I should write a review. It's been a long time since I last played but I adore this game. Adorable art style, cute and funny characters, combining management, capitalism and combat. It's even easy to replace music by renaming files xD. Might not have enough content to keep people happy, but the things you are taught at the start is more or less exactly how the entire game is going to be like. If you like the opening few days or week, you know what you're getting into.

The combat isn't the best but it's there and it functions. Randomly generated dungeons can be fun or a chore depending on how you see it. The game might be over because of a few unlucky moments in succession, like failing to get a piece of random drop loot you needed to get you through the next payment or to upgrade your chosen adventurer. Game Over however isn't the end, because this game has automatic New Game+ system. If you lose, you start over with all the progress you made, letting you use the new options and abilities you unlocked to speed through early game and hopefully set you up for a win next time. There is also a true New Game+, you can start a winning file over and get another reward for beating the game, usable in the next playthrough.

There is a lot of grind involved if you want to get everything and luck is a major component in that. There is some complexity involved in the shop management and buying/selling game, but there are some tips online to make it less of a hassle.

Ah, Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale. How delightful to have encountered such a beguiling game, which subverts the tired conventions of the JRPG genre by presenting the player with a fresh, engaging, and oh-so-clever concept: running an item shop.

As one who frequents the most esteemed art galleries, I am particularly enamored with the game's presentation. The charming, anime-inspired graphics are a breath of fresh air in a medium that is often overly preoccupied with hyper-realism, and the lovingly crafted pixel art adds a sense of nostalgia that is sure to delight any connoisseur of the retro-gaming scene.

But it is not merely the aesthetics that draw me to Recettear. No, what truly sets this game apart is its masterful blend of mechanics and narrative. The player assumes the role of Recette, a plucky young girl who inherits an item shop from her absentee father, and must use her wits and savvy to navigate the cutthroat world of commerce. As she purchases and sells various goods, the player is treated to a richly woven tale of friendship, betrayal, and adventure, complete with lovable characters and unexpected plot twists.

But what truly elevates Recettear to the level of high art is the way in which it grapples with the themes of capitalism, class struggle, and the intersection of commerce and human relationships. As Recette struggles to keep her shop afloat, she must contend with the demands of various factions, including the guild of adventurers, who rely on her wares to survive their perilous journeys, and the wealthy nobility, who seek to exploit her for their own gain. Through it all, Recette remains steadfast in her belief that the value of a person is not determined by their wealth or status, but by the relationships they cultivate.

In conclusion, Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a truly remarkable achievement in gaming, and a work of art that is sure to delight and challenge even the most discerning of critics. Its blend of mechanics and narrative, coupled with its richly realized world and thought-provoking themes, make it a game that is not to be missed. I daresay it belongs in the Louvre!

Recettear is a charming and addictive game that will have you hooked from the very first sale. This game is all about capitalism, neglectful parents, and overcharging villagers – and it's a blast to play.

As the titular character Recette, you're tasked with running a small item shop in a bustling town. You'll have to haggle with customers, manage your inventory, and keep your store stocked with all sorts of goods. And let's not forget about the dungeons – you'll have to delve into dangerous dungeons to find rare items to sell.

The game's graphics are adorable, with bright colors and cute character designs that are sure to put a smile on your face. And the soundtrack is just as charming, with catchy tunes that will have you humming along.

But what really sets Recettear apart is its humor. The game is full of puns and witty jokes, and the characters are all quirky and memorable. From the lazy slacker who runs the item shop next door to the creepy old man who hangs around the town square, you'll meet all sorts of colorful characters in Recettear.

Of course, the game's core mechanic is buying low and selling high. You'll have to be savvy with your pricing if you want to turn a profit, and sometimes that means overcharging your customers. But hey, that's just good business!

Overall, Recettear is a gem of a game that's sure to steal your heart. With its addictive gameplay, charming graphics, and hilarious humor, it's a must-play for anyone who loves a good capitalist adventure. So grab your wallet and get ready to haggle – Recettear is waiting for you!

Charming little game, even if a little unbalanced.  You own an item shop indebted to a loanshark fairy, and every week you have to make payments.  This goes on over the course of five weeks, the payments getting steeper every time.   Each day is broken down into a few segments, and you can choose to open shop, go to the wholesalers to obtain more stock to sell, redecorate or rearrange your items/shelves, or go dungeon diving to gather loot yourself. 
The main gameplay loop is you opening your shop each day, haggling with people who want to buy stuff from you or sell their junk to you.  Buy-low, sell-high is the name of the game here, with the risk being that each character is unique and is willing to pay only so much, and only so much over the base price of an item and if you push them too much they will give up and leave.  And there's variety thrown in through, as the time of day and the days change, the prices of different categories of items rise and fall in the general marketplace, which directly affects how you buy/sell.
The problem is, it's pretty opaque.  It's upfront in telling you whether an item is selling high or low in the marketplace, but beyond that it leaves you to your own devices.  Rarely will you get customers taking the 30% margin markup the tutorial tells you.  You end up establishing in your own head rough patterns for different characters for what they're willing to pay or be paid, which stays fairly consistent for a time, maybe a day or two, but this seems to change then with no real rhyme or reason (I'm looking at you, annoying little girl brat shopper).  And there were times where it didn't matter how much I eroded my profit margins for some characters, they still weren't willing to pay anything, and stormed off.  I'm not sure if it was random, but it was pretty baffling altogether.

And to make matters worse I found, with the best will in the world, it was completely impossible to win the game first time round.  Unless you're already an expert and are min-maxing your way through it.  But once you fail by missing a payment date, you go back to start of the 5 weeks, BUT you keep all your items and level (which isn't really explained by the way).  So it becomes trivially easy.  I found I had enough saved within about 3 weeks of my second loop through the game to pay all remaining loan, but there was no option to do this early, or fast advance time. I had to keep leaving and re-entering my shop constantly to make time go forward so I could watch the credits which seems like a silly oversight.  But then again it is an old game with rough edges.

There's a whole dungeon-diving aspect to the game but it is very basic and repetitive and not the focus here, and honestly on my second loop through the game I didn't bother with it at all.

So with all that said, it's a tentative recommendation provided you know what you're getting into and can handle the jank.

Recettear is a story driven shop simulation game with zelda-style action gameplay. The plot and characters is one of the game's strong points. The protagonist, a little girl named Recette, is told by a debt collection fairy named Tier that her father died and left behind a huge debt and she's come to repossess her house. They work out a payment schedule of escalating amounts each day and quickly convert the house into a fantasy item shop.

The core loop involves buying and selling items from customers, arranging the shop, and haggling prices. There are places in the city that you can visit, but that takes time away that could be spent making money in the shop, forcing the player to manage their time carefully. Once you meet adventurers, you can hire them to explore the dungeon with you to find items to sell. Dungeon gameplay feels reminiscent of Zelda to me.

I've played other shop management sims, and I think this one is among my favorites due to the ticking clock and escalating debt repayment costs. If you haven't played this and love shop management sims, you should give this game a shot.

118551413.review:
This is quite possibly the cutest capitalism simulator ever.

When Recette’s father disappears on an adventure, at first she doesn’t think too much of it. Until, that is, a fairy named Tear shows up and says that her father borrowed a staggering amount of money and used their family home as collateral. Faced with potentially being thrown out onto the street, Recette is determined to pay off her father’s debt. Tear (unusually for a fictional loan shark) would rather help Recette pay off the loan than break her legs and has come up with a business plan: Open an item shop on the house’s  lower floor - an item shop which Recette dubs Recettear in honour of their new friendship.

The player must then find a balance between buying from customers, the merchants’ guild, and the market, and selling to customers at a profit. By the way, buying from and selling to the customers at the correct price points will also level them up, meaning they have more money to spend in your store! Do well enough and you’ll pay off the weekly installments, which get bigger as the month progresses. Fail, and it’s out on the street for you.

There’s also an RPG dungeon-crawling element: You can hire adventurers to explore dungeons, slay monsters, and collect loot. Some of the loot can also be used to create better quality items which sell at a higher price point.

Recettear is a thoroughly enjoyable and adorable game. One of the best aspects, though, is the cycle of  new game plus - something common in JRPGs which is used to great effect here. If you fail to meet a repayment (or complete the game and choose to start again), you will restart with all of your stock still in your inventory. This means that if you know you can’t meet the repayment, you can just spend all of your money to get items which will make the next run easier. The customers and adventurers will also retain their levels, which helps as well. So despite being very challenging the first few runs, the game is also very forgiving in allowing you to learn from these challenges.

When it comes to the graphics of Recettear, the first impression is “Fuck that’s cute”, and this impression doesn’t fade. Even the monsters the adventurers beat up are cute! (I still enjoy killing the bastards though.) The sound design is also very good, with music which always puts me in a good mood - I would honestly pay for the soundtrack if it was available. The game also runs very smoothly,  with little to no bugs that I could see.


Top 5 Pros:
	- Cute as fuck
	- No romance in sight (but you can ship to your heart’s content)
	- Cast have a diverse set of personalities
	- The cycles of new-game-plus allow for a lot of forgiveness
	- Adjusting your shop atmosphere for different customers


Top 5 Cons:
	- Combat is very basic
	- Lack of diversity in skin colours
	- You will probably be thrown out into the street at least once
	- That irritating-as-fuck little girl
	- Euria. Fuck you, Euria.


Would I recommend?
Yes. Wholeheartedly.

(More reviews at www.quirkyandcute.com.au)

117256671.review:
https://youtu.be/d3uKZA9qpsU

Recettear is a cute little fantasy game about the harsh realities of loansharking. It’s stars Recette, a girl whose absent father took up a loan that he hasn’t paid back yet. Because of that, Tear, a fairy sent by the company that lent Recette’s father the money, shows up at her doorstep and demands incremental payments to clear her father’s debt over a span of five weeks. And that’s basically all the setup we get. Recette has money trouble and decides to turn her home into a store to sell a variety of items to fellow townsfolk as well as adventurers who frequent the town. I like this role reversal. 

In terms of gameplay, it’s mostly straightforward. To run your shop, you first have to acquire a bunch of inventory. You have multiple ways of procuring said stock, either from a market, the merchant’s guild or by sending off adventurers and tasking them with bringing back items or ingredients to craft better items.

The first two are rather self-explanatory. They’re a bunch of dolled up menus that show you what’s on offer so you can buy it as stock to sell later on. The adventuring portion is a bit more involved though. You can recruit a couple of adventurers over the course of the game to go into a half a dozen dungeons to retrieve ingredients and gear. But the twist here is that it’s not just a passive affair. You get to go along into those dungeons and the game hands you control over the adventurer you’ve hired, to engage in some light combat gameplay while wandering around randomly generated dungeons.

I’ll be honest, the dungeon crawling aspect didn’t really resonate with me all that much. It’s too simplistic to be entertaining and it also unnecessarily detracts from the other half of the game. I mean, it’s right there in the title, it’s “an item shop’s tale”. I feel like the inclusion of the playable dungeons detracts from the central idea the game is built upon. It’s literally just a bunch of tacked together combat spaces filled with a random assortment of enemies that mostly exhibit the same behaviors and aren’t tough to deal with. The uninteresting dungeon crawling coupled with the tacit betrayal of the game’s central gimmick left me with a general unwillingness to engage with that aspect of the game all that much. And since that part of the game is also the one that nets you all the ingredients for the crafting system, I also never engaged with that in any meaningful capacity.

Once you have a bunch of stuff to sell, you can return to your store, put the items onto your shelves and watch customers flock in to see the wares on offer. If a customer shows interest in a product, you get to haggle over the price until they’re happy with it or they eventually refuse to buy from you for not meeting their budget. Japanese games have a tendency to systematize a lot of their gameplay. And while haggling over the price is a central mechanic that gets extensively tutorialized at the start, it’s actually counterintuitively not what you’re supposed to do. The game tells you that typically a sale price of 30% above the base price is acceptable to most customers. 

This initial “strategy” of aiming for those 30% ended with me missing one of the payment milestones by quite a margin. At that point, the game actually sent me back all the way to day 2 of the calendar to try again, so it has somewhat of a roguelike quality, even though you can manually save at any point and just load up that save to continue where you left off previously.

But here’s actually where the game took a turn for the interesting. Because even though all my money was gone, my inventory, merchant level, dungeon progress, etc. was all still there. So while the game is content with letting you screw yourself over royally the first time around, you basically don’t get punished that hard for failing at it. And the fact that you get to keep everything except the money means that you’re now much better equipped to deal with upcoming challenges.

The game also introduces market fluctuations that affect the prices of your items. If prices sink, you’ll generally have to sell your items way below their base prices. A way to get around that is by simply not stocking these items. Characters typically only buy what’s on the shelves. Sometimes they come up to you and ask for an item in a specific category, so if you have something there you can choose which items you want to sell. For these discounted items, I usually went with the cheaper ones, so selling them wouldn’t eat into my profits. Conversely, there are also times when items can be sold for much more. 

These scarcities actually led to a few in game days where I had such massive profits that I had the necessary funds to pay back the loan almost a week in advance. Now this might not sound all that impressive, but the weekly payments increase at an almost exponential level, from a mere 10’000 at the start to half a million by the end. Unfortunately, there’s no way to then just jump ahead to end the game, you have to run out the clock by artificially moving around town a bit. 

And I admit that by the end I kinda got a bit tired of the sale mechanics, because at that point I figured out the behaviors of the characters and consistently managed to pull in way more money than necessary. The gameplay never really changes while you’re in the store. And yeah, I can hear you yelling “that’s what the dungeons and the crafting are for”, but they were also equally underwhelming, so it’s trading in one gameplay aspect for another one that isn’t that fulfilling and didn’t really seem to accelerate my financial growth anyway.

Here’s where a theme or a relevant storyline could’ve helped the game sustain my interest for a bit longer. The game starts off strong with the idea of a little girl being coerced into paying her father’s debts by the fantasy equivalent of a loan shark. And there are a few jabs at typical fantasy game tropes thrown in there for good measure, like the quite frankly ludicrous price certain items fetch in relation to others. But I just feel that most of that is fairly superficial and leaves a lot of unfulfilled potential on the table. I mean, Recette herself adopts the catchphrase “Capitalism, ho!”. That would’ve been an excellent angle to tackle a story from: make it a critique of capitalism. Make it about the struggle of being forced to work in a society that seems to be mostly centered around consumption. But no, as it stands, the game doesn’t really tell a story. It introduces a sort of antagonist partway through with Alouette, who runs an apparently competing business. But it never really materializes into an actual rivalry, and it has no impact on your ability to sell to guaranteed customers. All that happens is that she and her fairy show up periodically at your store to buy something. And for the record, those two are the ones who’ll never accept anything above base price, so they’re reduced to simple to navigate obstacles.

In the end, I’m not sure I can recommend Recettear. I mean, I’d be lying if I were saying that I didn’t have fun with the core item shop mechanic. It has this addictive quality to it, especially in the period where you’re still trying to figure out the systems. But once you do, it becomes pretty rote and the systemic nature of the gameplay becomes fairly evident. But ultimately, that’s not the primary reason why I wouldn’t recommend it. To me, it’s not that what I ended up playing wasn’t a masterpiece, but more that I saw so much more potential in this idea that didn’t get realized. A bad game is one thing, but I feel it’s all the more tragic if you play a sort of passable game that’s clearly standing in the shadow of the much better game it could be.

111589085.review:
Games that are made for the reason of flipping an established convention on its head in one way or another can often feel as if they have a lot of boxes they need to tick to feel worthwhile thanks to the fact that it not only needs to deviate from the norm pretty significantly, but then also prove the worth of doing so to begin with. Recettear is one such game that ends up picking up such expectations due to the way it manages to reverse the roles placed upon the player in a typical RPG. Rather than taking the position of a questing adventurer or the hero, the player instead gets to play the role of an item merchant in their day to day life as they try paying off their debts and expanding their business, and I'd say that the game does a good job at providing enough depth to this idea to support its playtime while still being very simple and accessible at its core, despite some issues that become increasingly clear as you play through the campaign. This combined with the uniquely offbeat sense of humour that's presented ultimately makes for an experience that I'd consider extremely worth playing through in spite of the flaws that it presents front and centre.

One of the most effective things this game does is introduce new concepts in an easily digestible and tangible context. While the options the player has at the very start of the game are limited, they still feel like enough to get by, as if you could feasibly get through stuff at the pace you're going at, but then the game continuously adds new elements to its core loop that expand upon it in extremely clear ways that benefit you nearly immediately. The biggest example of this is once the player is introduced to fluctuating market prices, where certain items suddenly spike or drop in value. While this contributes to a heightened sense of complexity as the game now rewards you for having a varied stock in the backlog to best capitalise on these changing prices for maximum profit, the way that it's initially presented makes it something not just to think about in the long term, but something you can immediately do and see both the benefits and drawbacks of relying on these methods, as while they're effective, they're also very unreliable due to the lack of control over the market itself. While easy to understand and contextualised through gameplay effectively, this sort of underlying, layered nuance is what makes the shopkeeping aspect of the game tick, everything looks and feels simple, but the lightly strategic elements in play if you really want to double down and best run your business (which the game inherently makes you do) end up breathing so much life into these systems. 

The writing is also really funny with the way that despite playing as this cute anime girl who's just trying her best to get by with what might seem to be righteous glee, the game makes explicit note of the way the tactics the player needs to use exemplify so much about the issues with capitalism, as you're charging absurd prices for even the most mundane of objects while also paying as little as possible to the desperate people selling of their possessions only to immediately charge triple the price, all while your main character is completely embracing it to the point where her main catch phrase is "capitalism, ho!" The rest of the game's writing matches this really well, painting this society as something that's clearly awful in a lot of respects, but having the characters seemingly embrace it in an entirely self-aware and explicit way, which creates quite a bizarre sense of humour that I can't say I've seen attempted to such an extent before, and I love it for that alone, because it makes for a truly special experience one way or another, even if it might not be for everyone. That said though, for as entertaining as it might be to be an airhead who's perpetuating the many egregious problems in society in such a lighthearted way, the game has one clear problem that heavily brings things down. 

While the entire shopkeeping section of the game manages to cleverly tackle genre conventions while still feeling like a distinct and interesting artistic expression in its own right and I genuinely think it's an amazing time, Recettear is brought down by the adventuring sections that the player has to pursue. A prominent way in which the player is able to collect more resources to put on their shelves is by hiring a mercenary to enter dungeons and essentially play a top down, procedurally generated dungeon crawler. My issues with this aspect of the game are pretty numerous as I feel that not only is the section pretty mechanically dry, but from a thematic standpoint I feel like it kinda goes against what the rest of the game was trying to do. For an experience that seems so deadset on subverting the many tropes of this style of RPGs, this section just feels like an extremely standard take on a top down dungeon crawler, with the experience really being nothing more than making your way through bland rooms and slaying waves of enemies to get loot, with not even a hint of more self-aware snarkiness or even something as simple as a proverbial wink to the camera, instead just being an emulation of the style of other games but just, worse. It also doesn't help that even from a purely mechanical standpoint, not only is this section pretty mediocre, but it ends up clashing with the other elements of gameplay and almost always just feels like a lesser option past the first few floors. The fact that the drops you get from the treasure chests don't remove lower tier items as you climb higher up often make these sections feel unsatisfying as you exit with a bunch of stuff that feels practically worthless, but still necessary to pursue in case you do manage to score a great haul. 

The crafting materials that you find throughout also don't help much due to the limited inventory space (what a surprise, me complaining about this stuff again) making you have to choose between taking more valuable items or taking ingredients to potentially craft something better, the issue being that the steep amount of these materials you generally need to make anything worthwhile ends up making this barely a choice, as it's almost always more beneficial to just take the items that are worth more than to try doing anything special with them. It all ends up becoming a game of irritation and you're just constantly throwing out items worth ever so slightly less than others to make minuscule additional profits, ultimately micromanaging in a truly unsatisfying way that also wastes time that could've just been spent getting significantly richer off of buying and reselling items in town. I ultimately just feel that this section doesn't provide sufficient reward for the time investment and risk involved, as losing an entire in-game day if you fall in battle is absolutely brutal and will impede your chances at being able to pay off weekly debts pretty significantly. Everything about the game seems to scream against touching this portion of the game at all, and yet there are too many incessant moments that push the player towards that all that I have to assume that they want you to heavily engage with it despite it being by far the worst aspect of the experience by a huge margin.

Overall, Recettear is a game that is an amazingly fun romp that manages to be equal parts witty and very silly and I love so much about what it does in certain respects, particularly everything related to the shopkeeping elements on display, but I can't fully embrace it and want to engage with it beyond its main campaign due to how hard the game pushes an entirely unsatisfying aspect of itself on the player. The amount of underlying nuance that the player is expected to figure out and best capitalise on is absolutely wonderful and provides further depth to such a deceptively basic time, but even so, if you decide you want to play this, be prepared for some moments of severe tedium.

7/10

There's not much I can say about this game that hasn't been said a thousand times. It's one of the most fun games based on the concept of running an item shop out there, a rather underused premise. It remains one of the most iconic games of its kind, and is often called the gold standard for haggling mechanics and the like.

But if you've found this game and are reading this review because you're still on the fence, you probably already know all of that and it hasn't convinced you yet. So aside from the accolades what are the game's selling points?

In terms of gameplay, the mechanics are solid. They're simplistic but they work, and there is definitely room to become more skillful if you really want. Apart from one character so far whose mechanics I dislike, I feel everyone plays well in the dungeons, and the shopkeeping and haggling is fun with a surprising amount of depth once you really dig into it.

I wouldn't say that's the main selling point though. For me it's the characters and vibe of the game. The soundtrack isn't particularly complex, but it's happy and upbeat without being overbearing, perfect for relaxing and enjoying yourself. The characters are cute, and usually likable (obviously this is a matter of taste, some characters I don't like are liked by others). The main story cutscenes are fine, but the optional little scenes you can find in game range from funny to genuinely cute and heartwarming.

Recettear is a game that feels good to play, it's relaxing, cute, and simple enough on the surface to just boot up and unwind with, while still having enough depth to try and challenge yourself and play skillfully, particularly after you unlock New Game+ and survival mode. 

Is it going to be your favorite game of all time? I'd say probably not for most people. There are going to be other games that do parts of what this game does better. But is this game worth your time? Absolutely yes.

108032631.review:
This game is...interesting.
In a good way.

I will start this by saying:
If you are coming into this for a definitive RPG Shop sim experience, this is not it.
You can't compare this title to things like Moonlighter, for example.
It has the bones and the fat, but it's lacking the meat to really push it over the edge.

Is it bad?
Not at all.
But it is UNIQUE.

What this game DOES deliver is a charming protagonist and a somewhat snarky comrade, making for some entertaining moments of dialogue, two game modes played in-tandem with each other, and hours of laid back, casual fun.

So let's pick it apart and see what you get from Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale:

Graphics:
6/10
They are a wonderful blend of early PS2 era 3D and 2D animations in terms of backdrops and character models respectively.
However, the thing that hurts this score is the inconsistent enemy graphics.
Some are really well done, and match the aesthetic nicely (Slimes and Mushrooms especially), but then you have these odd tentacle monsters and goblins that look like they were sourced from a scrapped Windows 95 3D game.
The monster models are too inconsistent to feel like they are part of a living, breathing world.

Audio:
8/10
The music in the game is very pleasant, albeit sometimes it muddies itself with too much going on in the background, especially in later adventure areas).
Sound effects from all sides are well placed and always appropriate for what is happening (From attacks, to characters, to enemies, etc.), and while some of these effects are definitely stock sounds, they fit well.

Story:
5/10
I'm going halfway on the story simply because a story exists.
It is a VERY simplistic narrative, but that doesn't mean it is not enjoyable.
You play as Recette, a girl who is burdened with her missing fathers debt.
Tear, her loan shark fairy, is tasked with receiving the payment in full.
Instead of giving Tear her home, she converts it into an item shop to pay off the debt in increments.
Aside from very few plot points along the way, that is...well, pretty much it in terms of the story telling.
It has other moments that act as subplots, but to avoid spoilers, you will have to discover those yourself.

Gameplay:
8.5/10
Now for the draw of the game.
Recettear sets out to present itself as an RPG shop Tycoon/Dungeon Crawler.
And it kind of is.
Kind of.
The main issue with a game like this is repetition can be cumbersome to casual players in the genre, and this game does not hold back on repetition.
Go into the dungeon
Loot a few floors
Return to shop to sell loot
Upgrade gear for hirelings for next dungeon outing
Loot a few floors
Return, rinse and repeat.
At its core, it is a simplistic game that I could argue would be PERFECT for a younger audience to be introduced into the Dungeon Crawler AND Tycoon genres with ease.
What it lacks to be a heavy hitter in either area is complexity and variety.
The combat is simplistic to the point of two buttons, but I praise the "pre-select items for each journey" inventory system.
The shop side of things, although the games focal point, is lacking more than the Dungeon crawling. And that is unfortunate.
You do not have "full control" over your shop.
You get pre-determined upgrades at certain merchant level goals, and the only control you have over items is a very simple haggling system when a customer picks an item. This same mechanic works the same for people selling items and requesting items as well.

Overall:
6.5/10
The lack of actual features hurts this otherwise interesting game.
But, I would go as far to say that this game likely helped pioneer the cross genre of RPG Shop Tycoon and Adventure title.
Is it fun?
Absolutely.
But how long it is fun is up to the individual.

I recommend this title for anyone looking for a sim or tycoon style game, but also a casual pick up and play.

94384119.review:
[h1]Capitalism.. good?[/h1]
Recettear is a "first of its kind" type of game, though I have no doubts there were shopkeeper titles before it.
The controls can be a little weird at first, but the overall polish helps immensely with easing into muscle memory. You won't have to juggle a keyboard's worth of binds, and it's very comfortably played with a controller.

In short, Recettear is about running a shop, and running that shop is actually pretty fun!

[b]What about the Negative Reviews?[/b]
[i]Sometimes you'll get a few saltines who essentially dropped themselves into a two-foot hole and blame the developers for letting them discard their shovel.[/i]

[i]"The dungeon is necessary to progress! I lose the game without it!"[/i]
[b]Not true.[/b] It's completely possible - hell, I recommend - to beat the game without ever touching the dungeon; and this is especially prudent when concerning the Challenge Mode. The name of the game is Aggressive Capitalism, my friends. Certain customers are willing to pay more for your product, it's about trial-and-error to see how far they're willing to go!

[i]"Very simple short game."[/i]
[b]He says at 26 hours.[/b] Your average playthrough, once you're familiar with the game, can be banged out in a night or two. Going for NG+/Challenge can tack on another ten - you'd average at around 30 hours. If you want to be reductionist and purely go for dollar:hour, Recettear often goes on 50-80% sales, and it's a steal!

[i]"Moonlighter is better."[/i]
[b]That's your opinion![/b] [i](and your opinion is trash)[/i]
In all seriousness, when compared 1:1, Moonlighter's focus is more on the (still pretty dry) combat rather than the shop. You don't deal with customers face-to-face, and it removes a lot of the charm of being a shopkeeper if you're serving items through glorified vending machines (which is also something you can do, optionally, in Recettear)!

[b]Brief Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Great translation work on the dialogue, and a fair few funny antics through the story
[*]A Sale-Chain mechanic that rewards keen customer service with quick levels and glorious feedback
[*]"Just deep enough" progression/unlocks, with a New Game+ and Challenge Run mode
[*]Meaningful (though limited) shop customization (themeing your shop draws in specific groups of customers)
[*]Plenty of shop item variety
[*]The dungeon is [i]not necessary to progress[/i] and can safely be ignored!
[/list]

[b]Brief Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Dungeon gameplay is extremely boring; a basic hack-n-slash that never gets better
[*]Little Girls are the worst customer type by design
[/list]

I find myself returning a few times a year to play through again, and I'm sure many others share the sentiment. There's just something about the satisfying feedback loop from running the shop that really scratches that micromanagement itch, without breaking out a game that requires you to read a few pages from NASA's handbook first.

Always recommend Recettear over Moonlighter, no contest.

93653011.review:
While the genre of Fantasy Shopkeeper RPG is relatively light in terms of choices, Recettear remains one of the best in this category despite being over a decade old, lacking mouse control, somewhat dated graphics and coming from a small indie studio.  What WORKS about this game?
    * The protagonist, Recette, is endearingly upbeat and innocent despite the cutthroat implications of it capitalist theme.
    * While the world-building is a bit of a mish-mash of fantasy, there are a lot of dialogue scenes that develop the various characters the protagonist meets, including Recette and Tear, the fairy business coach/loan shark who gives her advice on running the shop.
   * There are challenges in the dungeon delving and in the running of the shop, provided that you don't spend a lot of time looking up guides on how to win.  
   * Players get to make wide variety of choices that impact their playthrough, including which characters to level up via dungeon-scumming, how to decorate the shop, and when to expand its size to sell more stuff.
   * The UI is well designed and the you can rebind the keys you use for controls.
   * There is a lot of heart here.  While Recette says "Capitalism, ho!" a lot, you really benefit from NOT fleecing your customers every chance you get.  Knowing their pricing "sweet spot" (which inches up as you sell more stuff to them without haggling) is one of the keys to advancing the plot and finding out more about the various people who potentially work with you.  So the charm of this game isn't just about appearances and what's in the speech bubbles, it's thoroughly mixed into the mechanics of the game.  

As for the downsides, Recettear is not a highly tactical game.  The special powers that the adventurers you find to help you get into the grime of killing monsters are not super different from one another.  There are no ways to combine powers or to craft items to make them unusually effective versus certain boss baddies, since damage is damage is damage in this game.  It can feel repetitive as you go through the same dungeon several times just to get that one rare item that one of your customers REALLY wants.  Also, as I mentioned earlier, the sound and graphics of this game are nothing particularly special.  If Mega SFX or deep combat combos are what you are looking for here, you won't find them.  I should also mention that there is no romance or hentai elements here, for those gamers who have become accustomed to the hentai sub-genre of RPGs.  (And thank goodness for that.)

For a light action RPG with buy-and-sell at its chewy center, Recettear delivers an imperfect but delicious balance of key flavors for your gaming palate, if that is what you want.

92137628.review:
[h1]Capitalism, ho![/h1]

In the aspect of Item Shop, I am impressed by how plenty of other mechanics that simulate what a real-life economy would be like. You often get announcements proclaiming when an item or category is having a price increase or decrease. With that information, you either buy an abundance of the item or category for future sales or sell the items for an exorbitant markup. Sometimes an announcement will inform you of a potential boom which, if the right conditions are met, will result in a ton of sales in a single period. You can even cause a crash in the market for an item if you sell too much of it in a short amount of time. Indeed, there are plenty of intricacies in the free market you would never encounter in one of those backward command economies.

Besides the item shop, the other main component of the game is the dungeon crawling experience you receive from the Adventurer’s Guild. Throughout the game, Recette will acquire the business cards for various adventurers; you will require one to enter the dungeons. Every dungeon will have multiple floors with a different layout every time you enter it. Each floor is populated with chests, enemies, and a single exit you need to find, with every fifth floor involving a boss fight. The combat is rather generic and the enemies aren’t challenging to go against either, not to mention that it is a chore to trudge throughout the floor to find that one exit. Still, the boss fights are a fun break from the monotony of the dungeons and there exists story events and characters you have to go on an adventure to find.

The primary reason to go to the dungeons outside of story-related events is for the drops monsters provide. While you could sell these drops on their own, they can be kept to be used as fusion material. Fusion items include food, equipment, consumables, and decoration. While most of them are generally profitable to sell, the rest, especially equipment, can be worthwhile to keep and use for yourself. Fusing items tend to be a late-game activity, especially since fusion ranks are unlocked as leveling rewards, but the items you get are unique to the mechanic and can be the best equipment to get in the game.

Outside of the shop and dungeons, you are able to travel to other parts of the city of Pensee like the Chapel and Town Square just to see events. They don’t do anything gameplay-wise, but the interactions between different characters are joyful scenes to watch as they become more like story characters than just walking piggy banks. Of note are the scenes between Recette and Tear as they become more than just partners but also friends. Sometimes these events will provide bits of information about the world, sometimes they are there for pure comedic effects. I just like seeing them since it’s kind of like playing through segments of a visual novel.

In overall conclusion, this game does not only packed with content and personality that challenges you to comb through dungeons and a spend-crazy customer base on a quest for profits. I love how the game made you dive into the dungeons with the adventurers rather than you sit and wait for your adventurers to come back behind the counter table. This game has shown that the blending of Business and Time Management could be included in a RPG Adventure Stories Game. And it was this very feature that MADE ME LOVE THIS GAME EVEN MORE!!!

Recettear is a merchant game where you need to pay back debt by opening an item shop and haggling to your heart's content.  Beat it in 15.4 hours (after three tries) using a game controller.  Difficulty is medium.

Gameplay - There are two parts to the over all gameplay: the first being selling items at the shop and the second being the dungeon.  Figuring out the controls isn't too hard for either, except for the obscurity of where the menu button is (it's esc on the keyboard, and ended up being Left Bumper on the controller.)  You need the menu to access the calendar and save and they aren't straightforward in game about where exactly the menu is except that it exists.  So there you go.

- The Shoppe: This is where you will spend most of the game.  Tear will hold your hand explaining everything, but once you get the jist it's smooth sailing.  Sell high, buy low.  Take and fulfill orders.  The more you level up as a merchant, the more you can change how the shop looks, how many items you can sell, and from there how many people will buy things from you.  It gets a little same-same with the actual selling, but it's so charming and peaceful I sorta zoned out and enjoyed it the entire time.  There's a time limit per day of what you can do, so if you run out to town to buy stock or enjoy little cutscenes for the characters or gallivant off in the dungeon, you have less time to sell in the shop.  

- The Dungeon: This is where you go to collect rarer items and find treasures to sell. You can use the monster drops in town to fuse new items, which of course can be sold for more.  Most of the monsters can be jobbed easily enough, with a boss every five levels that may or may not keep you on your toes, and there are special scenes in the dungeons to uncover.  But for the most part the monsters don't drop good stuff enough (if they drop anything at all), you can only carry 20 items a jaunt, and while most treasures will help you early on they're mostly next to worthless once you get past a certain time in-game.  The boss battles were entertaining, though. 
 
Characters Part 1 - All the main characters are cute and memorable.  They all have cute scenes throughout the play through that you can uncover.  Recette is adorbz and Tear is hilarious.  

Characters Part 2 - A few of the characters you meet will eventually give you a card that will let you use them in the dungeon.  Each has strength and weaknesses, but for my first full play through I didn't feel all that compelled to try them more than once with the crushing deadlines looming over the shoppe.  I also didn't get all the charries unlocked on my first playthrough.

Variety - This is where the game slacks off.  There's enough variety to fully enjoy it the first maybe five hours.  After that, it starts to drag.  There are only around five npcs (not including friends you make) that shop at the store with their own selling quirks and limits.  You hit midway into the dungeons and the enemies recycle with and without different color combos, but with the same attacks.  The dungeons have different floor designs, with randomized layouts, but it comes down to the same plan of 'move around fighting the same monsters until finding the next door'.  

Homelessness - If you can't pay off the debt you're homeless and have to start over with the knowledge and items you collected.  Sadly Tear will explain how the game works all over again, and you'll have to experience the same cutscenes and meet the same characters, unlock the same dungeons, etc.  Thankfully if you hit esc on the keyboard you can skip these scenes.  Wish this was handled differently.  A few of my friends gave up after being homeless X times, and I can understand why.  Thankfully the full game, itself, is short (guesstimating 5-6 hours total).  

Post game/replayability! - There's a post game if you beat it.  In it you'll get multiple options of future playthroughts, from a debt survival mode to an endless no-debt mode where you can focus on collecting all the characters, to more!  So if you like it, there's more ways to enjoy it for later on.  



In summary, Recettear is a cute, often funny, chillax merchant game where you work to pay off debt and avoid foreclosure on your humble little shop.  It's niche and has many adorable quirks I fully enjoyed.  I'll probably pick it up and play again in the future.  Where it shines there's also a bit of repetitiveness to deal with that may turn some away after playing for so long.  If you're looking for nice little games with anime characters and want to ignore the world by selling in a fantasy shop, this is definitely the sort of game you'll like.

87384831.review:
Recettear is a capitalism simulator/dungeon crawler that I heard about after watching SsethTzeentach's review.  I've seen a lot of people got into this game from his review, and I can see why.  This game is a masterpiece.  

The story of a young girl named Recette Lemongrass.  She's not the brightest bulb in the pack, but she's optimistic and willing to take on new challenges in life.  A fairy loan shark named Tear visits Recette and informs her that her father had built up quite a large sum of debt, and since he's missing, it's up to Recette to pay up.

Recette and Tear decide to open up an item shop called "Recettear", which is obviously a combination of Recette's and Tear's names, where they sell to adventurers and townsfolk.  The inventory ranges from weapons, armor, and accessories, to food, treasures, and item drops from monsters.  Over the course of a month, Recette has to pay a certain amount back the debt to the Terme Finance Company, where Tear is employed.  This amount will increase as you get further into the story and you pay off the debt.  If something happens that you don't pay off the debt, Recette will lose her house and everything she owns, and she'll get kicked out onto the street doing God knows what.

As for selling items, you acquire items in a few ways.  You can spend your hard earned money at the Merchant's Guild, where they sell mainly weapons and equipment.  The Market is where you can buy foodstuffs, books, scarves, and treasures.  Then there's the randomly generated dungeons.  Obviously, someone of Recette's character can't fight her way out of a paper sack, so she hires an adventurer to fight in her stead while she follows him/her around as they progress through the dungeons.  As for selling items, a customer will approach you and you have to haggle the price that the customer pays.  Usually it's around 100%-120% of market value, give or take.  After your first successful payment, you'll eventually get bulletins where certain items will increase or decrease in price for a certain amount of time.  These bulletins will happen at random, so there's no way to predict these.

Going back to the dungeons, you're given an adventurer named Louie.  He's a capable fighter with a sword and shield, and he's willing to throw his life away for you because he also needs money.  You'll run into new adventurers as you progress, and each will come with their strengths, weaknesses, and unique abilities.  Your first dungeon will have five levels, and you can find treasure at the end.  Simple enough, but your next dungeons will have you fight in boss battles and gauntlets.  These battles will happen usually at every five levels you progress in a dungeon, and there's even some spots where you don't have to battle anything, just grab the treasure and leave through the door.  These spots will also be the only way you can leave the dungeon and have all your items you've collected.  Keep in mind that you have limited slots for your spoils, so choose what to take with you wisely.  And if you lose all your health while in the dungeon, you'll lose most of the items you've collected, but you can take two items of your choice with you, but it's more useful to not get killed.

With all this, you work day-by-day.  Time is split into quarters: morning, afternoon, evening, and night.  What task you do will take up one quarter.  The only exception is when going into the dungeons with your chosen adventurer, which takes up two quarters.  Going out of your shop and into town will take up a quarter, for example.

Recettear isn't a hard game, but there's plenty of stuff coming out of left field to keep you guessing.  It's a matter of building up your wealth and paying to keep you in your house and your job.  I'd say that for the most part, the dungeons are pretty simple, since you have a button for attack, abilities, and an ability selector.  The main story isn't terribly long, as to fully pay your debt takes a month in-game, which isn't bad.  And if you do beat the main story mode, there's plenty of post-game content.  You'll unlock New Game +, Survival Mode, and Endless Mode.  New Game + lets you keep most of your unlocked content, but you have to repay the debt again.  Survival Mode is like the main story, but you have to pay off the ever increasing debt until you can no longer sustain your shop.  Endless mode lets you go on with your business with no pressure from the loan shark.  There is some more story to be had in Endless mode, so there's still some loose ends with the narrative.  You also have an entire item encyclopedia where you can fill it out with all the items in the game.  With all this, Recettear offers an impressive amount of replay value.

Outside of the gameplay mechanics, the characters are very likable.  Recette is a great main character who takes the job of running Recettear head on, and her relationship with Tear becomes less business and more of a sisterly bond that works together to keep the business going.  She comes off as kind of a ditz, but she has her heart in the right place.  Tear is much more serious and is generally more focused on the task at hand.  She serves as foil for Recette's more lighthearted nature.  The rest of the cast is also really good.  I think what really makes me enjoy the characters is the dialogue.  There's some amusing interactions between the characters in Recettear.  My personal favorite character being Charme, who drinks more than a goldfish at the Pub.  

Overall, I really enjoy Recettear very much.  It's a charming game that's got a lot going for it.  I kind of wish there was a sequel to the game, but for what we have here, it's great.  The characters are memorable, the amount of items you can sell are varied and plentiful at just the right amount, the dungeon crawling is a bit on the easy side, but still really good.  I can't really think of any negatives about the game.  This is a game I can't help but vehemently recommend.  It even runs on my dinky laptop with potato level specs, so you don't need a powerful machine to enjoy Recettear.  The usual $20 price point is fine, but I think I got it on sale some time ago.  Still, I think Recettear is a classic.  

Lastly, I just gotta thank EasyGameStation for creating this game, and Sseth for his review in my decision to buy Recettear.  Unabashedly recommended.  CAPITALISM, HO!

NOTE: Watch out for a character named Euria in the game.  She doesn't play fairly.

Multiplayer: No
Completion: 15 hrs
Cards: No | Cloud: No
Save Location: Same directory as the game.

Recettear is a hybrid shop simulator and dungeon crawler and has the unique honor of being the first Steam game I ever bought. It came about at a time when I was into shopkeeping games, and I was looking for something with a little more meat to it. Recettear came recommended and I took the plunge and made my first ever Steam purchase.

In Recettear you play the role of a charming young girl named Recette as she is thrust into the role of a shopkeeper to pay off her missing father's debt. She is joined by Tear, a "loan shark" fairy, who manages the finances and teaches the biz to our young entrepreneur. Lacking a name for the new shop, Recette picks the name Recettear and a new shop is born.

The game does a good job guiding you on what needs to be done, and so I won't go into too much detail. The game is split into two distinct sections. During the shopkeep section, you place your wares on the shop floor and when the shop is opened, customers come in and make offers to buy the items. You may then make a counter-offer, and if the customer is not satisfied, they will make yet another counter. This repeats until the customer is satisfied or they become offended and storm off. Different customers have different budgets and tastes, and as the game goes on, you will unlock new features to tinker with.

Dungeon exploration involves hiring a single adventurer who you command to run through a series of realtime roguelike dungeons. Every 5th floor resides a boss and defeating the boss will open up an exit to allow you to either continue on (to conserve time slices) or to return to shop with all the goodies you procured. Ordinarily I enjoy dungeon crawls, but for whatever reason I didn't find the dungeon aspect all too fun. Thankfully it is possible to beat the game without going through the non-forced dungeons.

The graphics in Recettear are bright and colorful and suit the game well, catering to the young crowd. The music is fitting as well, being upbeat pretty much all of the time. I did not encounter any crashes or bugs so that's always good.

I rate Recettear a C. The whole process of haggling and dungeoneering both ended up being more repetitive than I bargained for, and multiple times I found myself taking long breaks because my interest kept wandering off, which contributed to the unusual amount of time it took for me to get around to beating it. While the game has a story, it didn't really do a whole lot of character development and there were some mysteries that seemed to be unresolved by the end. The game has some good ideas, I just want a more engaging package to keep it entertaining.

This game was surprisingly addicting to play when I first started playing. The main concept of the game is basically buying items for cheap and then selling them for a higher price to rake in profits. It seems really simple and easy, which it is but as you progress through the game and the story you can expand your shop, get access to more items throughout the town and the dungeon and much more.

There is essentially 2 parts to the main game and main story. The shop managing part where you go around town buying items for the lowest price you can and selling them at your shop to get as much money for them as possible. But then there is also a dungeon you can go into with a selected adventurer of your choice. The gameplay in the dungeon is very similar to a dungeoncrawler or rogue like game. There are multiple floors and levels all with their own unique enemies and treasures to be found. At the end of each particular area there is usually a boss fight at the end too and I got a lot of enjoyment out of beating each specific dungeon area in the game. And this part also helped the shop management part from getting to stale and overplayed because there was a dungeon to explore as well.

Even after you finish paying off your debt, which could take a couple of tries depending on how you go about doing it. There are still other game modes you can play afterwards such as endless mode and newgame+ You could also try and unlock the rest of the playable characters you can use in the dungeon as there is definitely a lot more than you think available to use and play, to add onto to that feature they even interact at your shop and will sell and buy items from you. 

All in all the game goes on sale quite often so I would definitely recommend you pick this up and give it a try! You might end up really liking it like I did to my surprise!

The Good:
+ Entertaining dialog ("Capitalism, ho!").

The Bad:

Being someone who first played it a couple years after release, this game left such an impression on me, I decided to re-buy it a year or two ago on steam. I will just say it is just as good as I remember it.

The game is very charming and the core loop is very fun... for a while. There isn't any variation really after the first week just bigger numbers and new clients. That is cool and all, but I wished something could really shake things up.

I find the dungeon crawling to be my favourite part of the game. There are a lot of very interesting and different heroes to hire, each with a different play style. I like the more rhythmic feel to the combat, ei: you need to actually time your button presses to be any good. But then again you need to do so much dungeon crawling that it too can become boring. The cheer number of drops you need to farm to craft anything is ridiculous especially at the later crafting levels. This is why I haven't gotten close to 100% in this game. I stopped playing at the point I beat the main game and then unlocked the final dungeon which just has too many floors.

Another thing I like about the game is all the little town exploring events that are all great for the story and one of the main reasons I actually finished this game. And don't worry, you can't miss an event... well to re-phrase it, just because an event could have happened and you didn't go to it, doesn't mean the event is gone. The next time you go to that area at that time you will see the event you missed.

Score Breakdown:

Graphics: 9/10, these are incredibly charming graphics that look just as good as ever.

Sound: 7/10, the music is rather nice, however I find it can be a bit repetitive.

Gameplay: 8/10, as I said before, the basics were really good, it just never really went anywhere.

Difficulty: This one is a mixed bag. It is very likely that you will fail the deadline, however doing so sends you back to day one with all your level, adventurers, and equipment all still there. This means it is impossible to truly "fail" and you will at some point on your savefile beat the game. On the contrary, if you don't want to easy way out and want to first cycle the game... I have bad news for you, unless you love min-maxing and are able to quickly find the most effective use of your days (or just watch/read a guide), you are going to really struggle.

Requirements: I dare you to find a PC made in the last 4 decades that couldn't run this game.

All in all I give this game a score of 8/10.

For a game with such an easygoing atmosphere and a core gameplay loop about optimizing a routine over the course of weeks, Recettear gets ridiculously harsh when it wants to be. The mounting thresholds of your weekly debt payments like to slam into you like a brick wall, and if you can't make them it resets your funds to 1000 and rolls the clock all the way back to Day 2. Thankfully it doesn't take your stock or skill levels with it when it does, but it's still quite a harsh punishment that can feel like it comes out of nowhere if you get too settled into the day-to-day routine of the game.

I could've dealt if it was just that, but further along the game introduces market fluctuations. And these aren't a minor percentage shift here and there, these are full-on multipliers that can crop up over the course of your lunch break and snap your store's profits in half, particularly if you have any kind of stock preferences and the game randomly decides that the economy crashed so hard that you have to sell your entire inventory at cost.

Frankly playing this game is like getting into some light gardening but every once in a while someone sneaks up behind you and just clubs you with a baseball bat. I didn't pick up a happy sunshine anime game about playing the shopkeeper NPC because I wanted to be more stressed than the guy who tackles dragons for a living.

[h1] Recettear: An Item Shop’s Tale Review | Arcade Theory [/h1]

There are two groups of people in this world: the rich, and the poor. The bourgeoisie, and the proletariat. The capitalizers, and the capitalizees. And then there’s the socialists, but they’re irrelevant to our American history. Recettear is a game that allows you to experience the joys of screwing people over with immorally-priced goods. You play as Recette, a little girl accompanied by a fairy named Tear—can you guess where the shop name came from? As you can infer from the title, the game revolves you running an item shop and managing the sales and stocks of your store throughout the whole day. It may sound mundane, but through the power of anime, they managed to make Recettear a very fun game to play.

Going through the introduction, you’ll swiftly discover that you’re in a whole lot of debt thanks to your vanishing father. It’s a huge debt, but rest assured; Tear’s got your back. Every week, you need to pay off a progressively increasing portion of your debt, and you will by buying low and selling high. At the start, you don’t have much capital on you, so head down to the Market and Merchant’s Guild to buy some starting merchandise. Head back to Recettear and put your new products on the shelves. When you’re ready to start the work day, flip on the open sign and let the customers flow forth.

Each customer, be it a little girl or an old man, will have their own range of how much they’re willing to buy or even sell an item. A big portion of the game revolves around you trying to figure out how much to sell an item for to a specific character. Perhaps in one deal, a man will agree to purchase something for 120% of the price. If you try 130% in another deal, he will attempt to bargain the price down. And perhaps if you tried to sell the item at 140%, he will outright refuse the deal. There is a specific cutoff percentage for every patron where they will always be guaranteed to purchase without hassle, and it’s your job to figure out what that percentage is (hopefully without looking it up).

And it pays to find that sweet spot as every successful transaction results in merchant experience. When you successfully haggle at that sweet spot, you get a bonus to that merchant experience that can be chained to create a combo giving even more experience. The merchant experience will increase your merchant level which unlocks new features and mechanics for you to discover. In addition, getting that bonus will net a significant gain to customer reputation. There are a few benefits to increasing customer reputation, but the primary one is that their spending budget increases when it is leveled, meaning that the little girl who couldn’t afford a cherry now has the expenditure to do so. once you get Recettear figured out, it turns out to be rather easy and one-note. This doesn't change the fact the game is charming and can be fun. Recettear's biggest appeal is its so different and unusual it offers a completely new experience you've likely never had. This is helped along by the fact Recettear's concept is simple and functional. Everything about this game feels like a throwback to the PS2 era so much so I'm surprised it isn't a port. This includes Japanese developers willingness to take risks making unusual, experimental games like Recettear.

I"d actually say Recettear is worth picking up at full price. But if you like to stretch your dollar; it goes for $4 or $5 during Steam's big seasonal sales. Its totally worth it.

The weakest thing about Recettear is the dungeon. Its easy to misunderstand the dungeon's purpose thinking the point is to plunder treasure chests. Yes, you can do that. But the dungeon is really meant for collecting materials to fuse better, more valuable items to sell. The dungeon is also rather simple, crude, and not that difficult. Its not bad by any means, but it can be boring.

Also, if you have trouble with the shop aspect of Recettear, the basic philosophy you want to follow is every transaction is successful 1st try. A string of successful trades makes shop XP go up faster to access shop improvements.

little girl: 110%

man: 120%
male shopkeep: 125%

73649117.review:
I will recommend this game, but not wholeheartedly. There are a lot of things I absolutely adore about Reccetear, but it's difficult to wave away the numerous glaring flaws that almost made me hate it.

The sales process is poorly explained and tedious. I wound up having to look up details on a wiki to fill in the gaps left by Tear's awful explanation of sales mechanics. The 120-130 pricing rule was not the catch-all I was lead to believe, and it wound up creating a lot of confusion for me when it didn't work consistently. There's also NO EXPLANATION of how 'just combos' work and how easy it is to miss these when following utilizing the haggle strategy suggested by Tear.

It's also very difficult to play this game without taking notes and frequently updating them since there's no way to track your reputation gains for various characters (this could be easily fixed by displaying hearts during transactions). I also find it frustrating that I have to memorize a percentage for the normal, high, and low categories for both buying and selling. I appreciate that the devs wanted to make the sales process more complex, but there aren't enough in-game information tools to compliment this.


While the story isn't anything grand, it was quite pleasant overall. I appreciate the amount of love and care that went into the character writing, and this is equally matched by the translation. While none of the characters are particularly deep or complex, they still have a lot of charm and are filled to the brim with personality. There wasn't a single moment where I felt the need to skip over any of the dialogue; the interactions were precious to me. I was especially fond of Recette's optimism and determination (and she's just downright hilarious at times).


The combat is sort of a mixed bag for me. The mechanics do have a fair degree of thought put into them, so it's not all bad. Slow animations for the critical hits make it so much fun to land them, and I appreciate how well the specials are balanced. And even though it can get a little repetitive at times, I think it's both endearing and helpful when Recette reacts to your hero taking damage. The enemy variety is nice, and never feels like the game throws too many new creatures at you. 

That said, there are some monsters with seriously annoying mechanics, so that kinda detracts from the experience. No matter how much I fight the same monster, I can never control for the mechanics that contribute to my frustration (like the ghosts disappearing after ONE HIT and the blasted flying pumpkin heads). I understand the need to make the game challenging and whatever, but there needs to be some kind of combat advantage that eases the player into fighting these guys as time goes on.

Also, whose idea was it to have floors with double defense power? That's just wrong...

The dungeon navigation is also kinda meh. Sometimes I feel really frustrated whenever I have to navigate an expansive floor since the incentivizes you to hunt down treasure chests since they contain loot that you won't find anywhere else. That leads to lots and lots and lots of running to cover all of the terrain (and no consistent boosts to run speed).

Lastly, the mod support isn't there. Not sure why, but modding isn't a thing in this game, and it should be. If I could at least get a QoL mod to address most of the flaws I've written about, I might even be inclined to play this game to completion. But it's not, so I won't. Damn shame, too.

I won't recommend buying this game for more than $10. It's good, but not $20 good.

Probably one of my personal favorites, I come back to play through it every year or so. (My play time is not accurate) There's a lot of ways to play through this game, pretty much any option will work eventually as long as you grasp the mechanics, but if you try you can figure out some truly spectacular ways to make cash in complex ways that involve a fluctuating market and a bundle of cleverly marked pixie dust. 

This game is so cute it's gonna put a smile on your face, but it's also brutal in a way that punishes for mistakes without ever really making you feel punished. I feel like some jokes would fly over a younger audience's head, but it'd be a very good way to teach them the basics of finance regardless. It's just, very intuitive in a way that I honestly think made adulting easier when I got older. It taught me to save, and it taught me to keep track of complex situations and finances well before I needed to start doing that.

The point of the game is simple. Pay your debts while not becoming homeless. You will fail, and then you'll be turned back to try again with all your skills and any items you've managed to keep. Which is again, very similar to real life. When you fail you may lose your project, or your home, or any number of things, but you have your skills and your only option really is to go at it again.

I'm not gonna try and pretend Recettear is some deep exploration of the world, it's not, it's a super cute capitalistic simulator that has a few lessons everyone could stand to learn, and manages to be genuine fun while you're at it.

10/10, would live in a box again. In fact, I will when I get back to it next year.

72633125.review:
Recettear is a fun simulation about being in debt and screwing over a whole town with shoddy and suspicious goods, that do not seem to belong in a medieval fantasy setting. Sell high, buy low; capitalism ho, that's what you are.

The game's meat is built around time and resource management. Your success is measured on how well you have utilized the time segments in a day. In other words, you had better earn some money in every segment or you're going to be moving in a cardboard box. I've been through that scenario, it is not fun.

What makes this harder is the absolute, destitute bums that enter your store. You've worked hard for an item your inventory and some moronic kid on an errand is trying to scam it off you for 20% the market price. God forbid if you cannot meet their demand on your second offer; there goes your customer and your chance of raising your merchant level. Not that you had any hope to begin with; that gutter trash's wallet has never seen money.

The game is very enthralling and intense. I have been reduced to screaming, "Get out of my store" at my monitor, after the third customer asking for a bowl of beef soup has refused to buy it for 80% of its market price, then having some old alcoholic try to sell me his worthless, moldy candy apple to "help with his pension." This is a store, people. Please have some money ready before you enter it, I am trying to run a business, and my loan shark fairy has no qualms over kicking me to the curb if I fail to deliver so much as a cent of my weekly payments.

Personally, I would wholeheartedly love this game if it wasn't for the dungeons. Dungeons are the meat and potatoes of acquiring (proper) inventory through the fusion system. Let me explain: Dungeons contain critters that drop ingredients that cannot be bought or traded upon their demise. You use these ingredients to manufacture items that are valuable, powerful, and unobtainable through any other means. Can you skip the dungeons? If you do not know how to abuse the market system, no. The player is forced to run through the same corridors with a limited inventory, hoping to get something that allows them to live for another week. 

The dungeon grind is tedious and boring, not difficult or challenging in any other way. You can have some podcast running in the backround, while you press the movement keys and attack key to slog through the video game equivalent of a work day at the office cubicle. Why is there not an "autocrawl" -option? This portion of the game would at least be tolerable, if it were something like Darkest Dungeon's way of handling it.

Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10. The story and merchant simulation is fun. To get to the fun, you need to work through the molasses slog of the dungeons.
