72214749.review:
Recettear grita indie a los cuatro vientos, y es su mayor baza.

Interpretamos el papel de Recette, una niña con un padre de esos que dejan deudas en herencia, que se ve envuelta en una cruzada capitalista motivada por la empresa de cobro. Esto supone un giro en el clásico Dungeon Crawler, siendo nosotros los aventureros a la par que los dueños de la tienda de items.

El juego se basa en las clásicas mecánicas de comercio; compro barato, vendo caro. Esto encaja con las fluctuaciones de mercado que se nos presentan cada día e incluso a mediados del mismo de manera aleatoria, obligándonos a replanificar nuestra gestión del tiempo y los artículos en exposición. Estas fluctuaciones afectan muchísimo a la hora de regatear con los clientes, porque vender un artículo al 100% de su precio es inaceptable si el viejo de turno quiere la espada de moda para su nieto y se la podemos colar a un 250%. De todos modos no debemos excedernos a la hora de regatear, puesto que nos interesa mantener un combo de transacciones inmediatamente exitosas para obtener una bonificación de experiencia de incluso más de x10 en cada transacción. Esta experiencia de mercader permite el acceso a más objetos, más oportunidades de regatear, ampliaciones de tienda... al fin y al cabo, complica el juego a la vez que nos da acceso a mayores márgenes de beneficio si somos capaces de aprovechar cada nuevo elemento que se incorpora.

En Recettear el día se divide en 4 etapas de tiempo:

[list]
[*]Abrir la tienda consume una etapa y es la principal forma de obtener dinero. Si no obtenemos una meta establecida al final de cada semana, será el fin de la partida, y deberemos empezar de nuevo, arrastrando principalmente nuestro nivel de mercader, que como he dicho anteriormente enriquece mucho la experiencia y hace menos pesado este proceso dado que nuestros márgenes de beneficio son mucho mayores que la vez anterior y las metas son más fáciles de cumplir por este motivo.
[*]Ir al pueblo consume una etapa y es la manera de reabastecer el inventario de nuestro comercio. Conviene comprar artículos con baja demanda porque son más baratos, pero debemos tener de todo en caso de que un cliente lo pida para no romper nuestro combo de transacciones. En el pueblo podemos participar en conversaciones que desarrollan pequeñas subtramas entre los personajes que iremos conociendo durante la aventura; nada serio, pero sí un toque encantador si te gustan este tipo de cosas. Desde el pueblo también podemos salir de aventura
[*]Salir de aventura consume dos etapas de tiempo y es la parte Dungeon Crawler de Recettear. Sinceramente, ha envejecido mal. Esto no quita que sea entretenido para librarnos de la rutina del capitalismo y obtener artículos para la tienda prácticamente a coste cero. Esta mecánica tiene varios puntos limitantes con el fin de balancear el juego; solo podemos llevarnos veinte artículos, algunos de los cuales serán un misterio hasta que abandonemos la mazmorra. Si da la casualidad de que morimos, solo podremos llevarnos uno de los veinte. Los controles y en general el flujo de este apartado son toscos, más aún de lo que cabe esperar en un juego de diez años, pero esto no merma la experiencia en general puesto que es algo casi opcional y anecdótico si lo que nos interesa es puramente el comercio. 
[/list]

Una de las mecánicas más curiosas reside en los personajes que van con nosotros de aventura. Los iremos conociendo poco a poco y se nos irán uniendo, pero todos tienen un equipo bastante cutre en primer lugar. Si bien podemos prestarles el equipo, eso supone menos ranuras de inventario que las ya escasas veinte, y si somos derrotados perderemos la mayoría del equipo al solo poder salvar un artículo. Pero estos aventureros a veces vienen a la tienda, lo cual nos ofrece una vuelta de tuerca sobre la gestión de equipo: Si mi aventurero espadachín viene buscando "un arma", le ofreceré mi mejor espada y le haré incluso un descuento. Si un aventurero viene buscando equipo y podemos darle algo que sea adecuado para él, se lo equipará, obteniendo una mejora sustancial en nuestras aventuras posteriores.

Cabe destacar que este juego no está en español. No necesitas una gran cantidad de vocabulario para entender qué quieren los clientes, pero tampoco deberías ser completamente agnóstico al inglés (o japonés) si quieres disfrutarlo un mínimo.

Recettear es un juego corto y encantador que ofrece muchísimo. Es complejo, te obliga a pensar a corto y largo plazo constantemente, requiere de habilidad para superar su tosquísima parte de Dungeon Crawler y pensamiento analítico y crítico a la hora de jugar con los márgenes de beneficio, los regateos y los combos de transacciones para poder llegar al pago semanal con suficiente margen como para reabastecer la tienda y suficiente nivel de mercader como para poder llegar a la meta de la siguiente semana con las nuevas opciones que se irán abriendo.

Si no te has cansado aún de pagar deudas al maldito mapache usurero de Tom Nook, empieza a pagar deudas también en Recettear, no te arrepentirás.

[h1]Recettear in a nutshell[/h1]

1. [u]Buy copious amounts of walnut bread[/u]
2. [u]Sell it to poor people at inflated price[/u]
3. [u]Watch them suffer. Laugh, rinse and repeat[/u]

Jokes aside, under the guise of cutesy graphics and dialogues, Recettear perfectly encapsulates the many nuances of capitalism and it manages to make the theme appealing even to those people who don't know a damn thing about economics. For those who don't like the premise of managing your own shop, I can definitely assure you that you'll get addicted to this in no time anyway... Actually, it will consume you, and there's no turning back.

That's not to say it is all about buying and selling, or about keeping an eye out on how the market fluctuates every single day. It doesn't revolve around chitchats with the people in town either. This mundane life can become adventurous quite quickly, with a genre-shifting mechanic: you have the option (but not the obligation) to unlock and recruit mercenaries in order to overcome various dungeons... This way, the items you get can be sold at 100% profit!

Anyhow; I could write a lot about this title, but I want you to explore it yourself. All I can say is that I really didn't see any weak point whatsoever, it is truly a labour of love and as such, I highly recommend it.

I had this game for a long time before I played it but when I did, I enjoyed it a lot.

Running an item shop seems easy enough, but where do you get your stock? Dungeons, of course!. Teaming up with adventurers and killing monsters for item drops is fun and rewarding.

A simple game with some funny moments, it is quite easy to complete as long as you don't spend too much money.

You play Recette Lemongrass, a young girl who is forced to run the item shop attached to her house in order to pay back a loan her father had taken before disappearing. Your partner in this venture is Tear, a fairy who works as a loan broker and responsible for collecting your repayments.

During the game, you meet adventurers who will fight in dungeons for you in order to collect items to sell and some NPCs who have their own stories that you can interact with.

[h2]Pros[/h2]

* Interesting game play - Running the item shop becomes quite absorbing and the adventures through dungeons gets tricky but the rewards are greater.
* Haggling - Customers wishing to purchase your wares can engage you in haggling. Learn how your customers react to pricing and how much to take off to secure the sale with them.
* Funny moments - Customers don't just want to buy, some have items to sell and they will have stories associated with what they have. Some of these are amusing. "This belonged to my father. He treasured it all his life" and they offer you a ham sandwich.

[h2]Cons[/h2]

* Quite short and easy to complete the main quest line of paying back the loan if you know how to make a lot of money.
* NPCs tend to be forgettable and some are a bit shallow (in terms of narrative)
* [spoiler]The woman trying to rip you off becomes a pain after a while[/spoiler]

Overall, I am fond of these types of games and having played some more, I always compare them to this to see how they change things and what they bring to the table.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#471 out of 612)... it's time for Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale.

Now here's a game I really ought to have written a review of much, much earlier—for all the times I've gone around recommending it. Recettear is, in a word, brilliant. It's one of those rare examples of a totally new experience: a game that both invents an entirely new subgenre, but also remains at the top of that subgenre as all of its followers struggle to be even half so good.

So what is Recettear, exactly? It's a gorgeous chimera of a game. Part visual novel, part action RPG, part shopkeeper simulator. And while it not be the best visual novel, action RPG, or capitalism simulator out there, it is very much a creature far greater than the sum of its parts. Most of that is down to the storytelling, which binds each element together. Those familiar with NISA's games (EG Disgaea) will find the tone familiar: the storytelling is character-driven and often humorous, relying on strange characters of limited capacity struggle to solve problems in inventive ways with no small amount of amusing misunderstanding. You play as the owner of an item shop in a traditional Japanese-style Roleplaying Game's starter town, and must venture into the nearby dungeons yourself in order to accumulate stock to sell off to the wandering heroes and pay off your debt. High drama is predictably eschewed in favor of humor and slice-of-life shenanigans. You won't be on the edge of your seat playing Recettear, but you'll find yourself laughing—or at least smiling at the heroines' antics—quite often.

As a slice-of-life style story might dictate, the overall structure of the game is fairly relaxing. You settle into a rhythm fairly quickly of alternating between simple dungeon-delving, inventory management, and reading through dialog scenes. None of the mechanics at play here are particularly deep or complicated or challenging—but that's part of the charm. Your goal as a player isn't to get rich or become powerful or defeat a foe, it's simply to enjoy the ride. Few games manage to be as perfectly on-point tonally, and fewer still manage to nail the specific tone of a relaxing fantastic adventure quite so well. Many games since have emulated Recettear, but they've often chosen to abandon the visual novel aspect of the game to focus more on item management and dungeon-diving. These games, in my experience, quickly become stale as the lack of a calming narrative context leave the core mechanics to tell a story instead, and that story is always the same: an unceasing cycle of constant consumption.

Recettear is brilliant precisely because it offers a little something to everyone in a very accessible—and contained—package. It's a simple and engaging ARPG with a little bit of "capitalism simulation" to give the game some depth without adding tension, and tells a simple, but enjoyable story to follow along the way. When Recettear launched on Steam in 2010, there weren't many JsRPGs on the platform and it quickly made a name for itself as one of the best. Today, in 2020, Steam's library looks very different—but I think Recettear still holds up remarkably well. Simply put, though many have tried, there's still nothing else out there quite like it.

Recettear is a cheerful, cute localization of a pretty rote game. There are a collection of systems here that could make for a pretty novel experience, but unfortunately most of them are deeply pointless, leading to a repetitive, disappointing buy > resell cycle.

The gist is: you run a fantasy item shop to pay off your dead dad's debt. In the course of everyday business, you meet adventurers, can sell them better gear, can hire them to partake in playable dungeon crawls, and can use the loot to either resell or craft into super extra fancy gear for further gains. The catch is that the dungeon crawling part of the game is time consuming, isn't particularly engaging, and has terrible drop rates. On top of that, the crafting is so impractical as to ALSO never yield you anything of value.

The end result is that you entirely ignore those three-quarters of the game in favor of running back and forth between your wholesalers and your store, making minor shifts to account for price & demand shifts until the game abruptly ends.  It was honestly a little odd, in that despite making an honest stab at clearing the dungeon content, the credits rolled when I was about halfway through them overall, having crafted maybe 2 pieces of meaningful gear and not even met all the adventurers. A completionist could play on past the credits for ages, but the overwhelming question remains: why *would* you?

Ultimately, it's cute and charming, but something like Stardew Valley seems overwhelmingly more engaging while hitting the same beats and enjoying similar status as a game you can continue indefinitely.

Started playing Recettear after reading a DeviantART post about 100% completion of it. I've completed four, twenty-hour run-throughs out of seven needed to start thinking about 100% completion. Expect 140 hours to get to that point, then a few hundred hours beyond that to get 100% completion.

Is the game fun for the first few run-throughs? Definitely. 

What is fun after the first few run-throughs? Every next run-through, you can focus on another character and get small bits of progression in terms of finally completing certain crafting recipes. You can get lucky and get a customer who sells you an item you definitely need. There could be a drop in a dungeon you've been waiting for for ages.

Is the game fun enough for many hundreds of hours of gameplay? I'd say not fun enough. In Pokémon Emerald, completion feels like progress - you can train each of your monsters and find optimal ways to train them, you understand more about game mechanics and there's distractions and diversions all the time, with a New Game+-type of mode which makes progression more satisfying and also harder. In Recettear, completion consists of doing the exact same thing a bunch of times, with the only progress being unlocking one item. Gameplay difficulty CAN be increased, just not if you want progression -- you need to choose between two types of New Game+, and the more difficult one does not carry over at all to the progression-based New Game+.

If you want a game to grind for completion, Recettear is pretty hardcore and a bit lacking in short-term goals to make - everything is very mid- to long-term goals. If you dislike that, perhaps Stardew Valley, RuneScape or other games with many more short-term goals are a better fit. If you like these long-term goals, Recettear is a decent option.

Recettear is a fun and relaxing game about running an item shop for adventurers... and managing your money so you can pay off your crippling debt. Paying debt managing money and paying taxes is fun right? RIGHT? all joking aside this game is very fun and relaxing experience.
The story is a pretty simple setting that your deadbeat father decided to become an adventurer and took a massive loan for equipment to do so and never returned. Now you have to pay off the entire loan and you do so by running an item shop. The gameplay loop is very simple but it has a surprising bit of depth to it. You will get items and gear for your shop by either going into dungeons with an hired adventurer or by buying off of the market and then you sell them to your customers. You can set up the items you want to sell on display and people will come in and ask to buy an item that they want then you set the price. If they like it they will buy it or if they think that it is a bit high then they will try to haggle to get a better price, haggle too much or start the price too high then they will just storm off and not buy anything. You will spend a lot of your time haggling with your customers to try and sell your stuff at as much of a profit that you can, while simple there are new things you learn and are able to do that add in depth to it. The fluctuating prices on the market of items and gear going high or lower and the adventures that you can hire coming into your shop to buy gear as upgrades so you don't have to loan it to them when going out into dungeons adds in a lot of interesting depth to the game. Buying up a bunch of metal items while the prices are down then sell them when the prices stabilize, or do you wait until there is more demand and prices go up to sell them for a even bigger profit, these are all really interesting decisions that you will be making throughout the game. All of this though would not be nearly as engaging without the weekly payment that you have to make. The payments start out fairly small but it quickly ramps up and is fairly challenging to make all the payments in time adding to your decisions with the debt looming over you.
While all the decisions on running the shop are fun and interesting there are some criticisms with the game especially with the dungeons. The dungeons are all randomly generated but they are so simple that you will quickly feel like you been through it all and controlling whatever adventurer you hire is not very interesting. While there are different characters that you meet and will sell to through out the story you mostly sell to the same generic old man, man, women, and little girl. Each character has their own preferences and willingness to the prices they will pay that you will figure out over time, but with such a small pool of people you'll figure out the best prices for all of them then it can get repetitive as you already know what price they would be willing to go for.
Despite the dull dungeons it is largely inoffensive and as such i did not mind that it was so simple and the somewhat small pool of customers did not drag the game down too much. Overall i had a great time with this game. Now if you'll excuse me i have a golden statue to sell and a little girl just came into my shop that i need to chase out.

61849434.review:
Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a shop management simulator mixed with some dungeon crawling.

This is a pretty old game, but it's one of the best shop simulators you can find on Steam. You play as Recette, a girl, who's suddenly tasked with paying off her father's loan by running an item shop. The story itself is really short, it ends the moment you pay off your last debt; it takes one in game month to complete going through the main story. Upon the successful completion of paying off all of these debts, your main save file becomes the endless mode free of worries and debts. It also unlocks New Game+ and Survival Mode.

Shopkeeping in this game is really fun. You can buy items to sell from other merchants, or go adventuring through dungeons in search of loot to sell. By default you start off with one available adventurer, but can unlock more later. To sell items successfully it's important to pay attention to local news, and also, memorise acceptable price for different customers. As you level up your merchant level you get plenty of nice skills to use, these also include customisation and expansion of your shop.

Summary:

- Short main story.
- Different game modes unlock when you compete the main story.
- Pretty simple, yet still cute artwork.
- BGM might get annoying during prolonged game sessions.
- You can expand, customise and decorate your shop as you level up.
- Dungeon exploration is pretty fun.
- Lots of different items to find and sell.
- You can accept orders from customers later on.

Overall, this is a very enjoyable game and I highly recommend it. If you're looking for a good shopkeeping game, then this is a nice one to pick up and try.

I wish there was a "maybe" option, but I will put "yes" since I have been having fun with this game though it's not was I expecting.

For those unsure whether to buy: this is NOT a dungeon delving game. If you want a dungeon game, there are lots of really great ones out there that will do you better than this one.

This is a cute capitalism simulator first and foremost, with a late game dungeon delving mini-game that you can really only get into after you've beaten the shopkeeping simulator portion of the game.

Time is so valuable in this game, and going into a dungeon so unprofitable and time consuming, that your only real choice to make it through the debt payments is to never go into a dungeon (or go in each one once just to advance the story), and then just buy and sell items from the wholesalers until you "win" the game and level up your shopkeeping. Levelling up your shopkeeping is how you unlock higher tier gear for your adventurers anyways, so you HAVE to keep doing it even though it's repetitive and brainless.

I've been playing for 28 hours and haven't managed to unlock any challenging dungeon content. So far the enemies and bosses are all squishy and predictable, and higher difficulty areas are gated by (story progression? NPC events? Let me in already!) BUT the shop simulator is pretty addictive, so it gets a reluctant thumbs up from me.

Reccetear is a game that has no mirror, whilst there are games out there that do emulate the role of a fantasy RPG salesperson, like Merchant released not so long ago, or moonlighter, reccetear has a special charm to it. The blend of the RPG elements, the shop keeping mechanics and characters, art style, all create something not easily replaced by other games.

Art wise this is a very fantasy anime aesthetic, whilst it tries to blend 2D and 3D together, it doesn't look awful. That said, it isn't a very big game, and it doesn't seem to have a large budget if the enemies in dungeons are telling a story of that. It's heartbreaking to see such a brilliant game so thoroughly ruined by unpolished balancing.

The optimum strategy:
1. Sell at 105%
2. Buy at 70%
3. Never haggle
4. Never dungeon

If you follow these steps, you will win easily. If you don't, you will lose horribly. Both of the game's two primary loops, haggling and dungeoning, are short-circuited by the bizarre way in which experience and reputation are awarded. The game never even tells you about pin bonuses or just combos. If you don't go online and read guides or the wiki, you'll burn out well short of the final 500k payment without ever earning a single pin bonus or just combo, and won't even know they exist.

Basically, this game punishes you if you try to have fun, and rewards you if you go online, get spoiled, and then spend all day doing the exact same boring thing over and over.

[h1][i]"Capitalism, ho!"[/i][/h1]

Being abandoned by your irresponsible father as he goes off gallivanting in search of adventure is bad enough, but to then realise the scoundrel has left you up to your eyeballs in debt as well?! Surely things can't get any worse? 

[h1]Well, actually, they can[/h1] 

How about a knock on the door from a representative from Terme Finance, who gives you the ultimatum: pay back your father's crippling debt or give up your property and enjoy sleeping in a cardboard box! 

You are Recette Lemongrass, a happy-go-lucky girl, considering your dire circumstances. You are forced to convert your home into a shop to try and appease local clients with items they are seeking. This often means lending an ear as they trundle on in and tell you of their troubles, be it love woes or neighbourly quarrels. The knack you are using here is to 'smell what sells'! 

Now here is where the game gets interesting for me, Recette can enlist local adventurers to dungeon delve for some of the rarer monster items. Between these missions, keeping your adventurers well kitted and your shop looking pretty and stocked up, you are working your little socks off to get out of debt!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

A cute game with addictive elements, if you are anything like me you'll love getting a bargain from the wholesale merchants and pawning off items for an inflated price tag and watching with glistening munny signs in your eyes as the profits roll in! Of course, they aren't your funds for long, as Tear, the debt collecting fairy will loom at the end of the week with an outstretched hand and a serious frown to swipe her share!

Do this often enough and on time, and you'll be spared the fate of the cardboard box!

50803076.review:
I've put so much time in this game. I've beaten the story at least three times over the years. This is one of my absolute favorite games! I have yet to find a game that even comes close to it in terms of fun and shop management. I do wish there were more patron sprites, but that my only gripe. I very much wish there were more games like it.

The items that patrons are looking for are tied to the morning NEWS system, so item demand changes from day to day. It gives the shop aspect a bit of spice and really drives you to pick up ANY deals you can get your grubby hands on in the markets.

It's nice to have a management game that doesn't fall too deep into micromanagement. It's a good game to lose yourself in and it won't drive you nuts with complex supply/demand systems. It feels and plays like you are running a homey little town shop. Since this shop is literally in Recete's house, that is exactly how it should feel. 

It is a pretty decent dungeon crawler too. I am almost positive there are dungeons I haven't found yet due to not triggering their arrival. The combat is super easy. Once you get the hang of always approaching a monster at an angle then you really don't get hit very much. You do have to be aware of your adventurers' level and items though, as even if you don't get hit often you can die really quickly if you pop into a high level area. I really love how you can give your adventurers a smashing deal so that they are better equipped in dungeons. The monsters can a bit repetitive, but since you do have to look for specific monster drops I guess it would be awful if certain monsters were more rare.

Overall, I love sinking time into this game. The main character is ADORABLE and the character interactions are super cute. The character back-stories have a bitty bit of depth in them. I wish there were more games like this all the time. About once a year I dig around on the internet with a search of "more games like Recettear". It has yet to find anything that comes close.

Excellent store simulator and dungeon crawler combo. The store management is nuanced, from what items you stock, where you chose to place display them, how you treat your customers, and how prices fluctuate. While you can nickle and dime your customers--buying low and selling high--they'll resent you for it. Your merchant rank also increases quicker if you're fairer, and the merchant rank gets you access to better products, upgrades, and more skills. Striking a balance between customer satisfaction and making profits is rewarding. I could go on, but there's so much depth without feeling overwhelming.

I actually quite like the dungeon crawling gameplay too. It's less hack and slash like Rune Factory 4 or any 2D Legend of Zelda, and more slow and methodical like Illusion of Gaia for the SNES or Magic Knight Rayearth on the Sega Saturn or even Secret of Mana. It's more focused on landing precise hits in specific positions. You do more damage if you hit an enemy from the side, even more if you hit the back, and if you hit enemy right before it hits you, causing a counterattack. Most attacks can be dodged if you take it slow as well. When dungeon crawling you hire one of several adventurers you play as, each with their own class, stats, skills, and equipment. They all play differently and you'll have a favorite. Random events such as double experience, double defense on enemies, and MP cost halfed also help spice up floors along with traps and treasure chests. I actually really like the bosses as most are puzzle bosses. I think what makes the dungeon crawling work is that it's in service to the store simulation. It gets you items to sell, introduces more characters, progresses the deeper story, and adds contrast.

That being said, the dungeon crawling could have improvements. I'll defend the slower nature but it could feel smoother. Later in the game, dungeon crawling feels less optimal. Also, once you finish the last week of debt and continue the story in Endless Mode, you'll be doing more dungeon crawling, making it feel a bit more lopsided. It's still fun as you need money from the store to buy better equipment and items. You also still need to increase that merchant rank to get accesses to more items and equipment. I think if the game had you go to the dungeon every night (like the inferior Moonlighter), it would have fixed this. You would also advance the story more naturally. And it would allow for you to have a better and more varied stock of items. You wouldn't waste most of a day or even a full day dungeoneering. It would also make the Endless Mode feel less lopsided towards dungeon crawling as you'll have more time to in the main game to get to where the game expects you to be in Endless Mode.

All and all, this game is great. The store aspect is really deep and satisfying, and the dungeon crawling offers a nice change of pace and can be fun in its own right. It's a game much stronger than the sum of its parts. The store simulation could be its own game but the RPG elements widens the scope. The dungeon crawling is fun, but the store aspect creates a risk-reward situation where you have to decide what stuff to keep or throw away with your limited inventory space as well as whether you should continue going down another five floors or head back now. You could get deeper but maybe die and lose everything. You could find some valuable items but your inventory is full and you need to start tossing stuff. Both gameplay modes set up and create a dynamic contrast for a great game.

48026987.review:
Reccetear has an incredible, deep story that tells the tale of humanity. You are a young girl in a small medieval European-style town, just living life as you please, when one day a representative of an international megolomaniacal banking corporation arrives to tell you you are in an enormous amount of debt. You begin to question the ethicality of familial debt enslavement for a moment, but quickly are thrust into having to navigate the market for sheer survival. Failure to pay your debt is death, so you persevere.

You begin small, selling old clothes and half-ripe apples. Buy low, sell high. As you get more customers, and the magnitude of the debt becomes apparent, you begin to grow your business. Selling little girls knives to take home to mommy doesn't seem right at first, but when you realize the profiteering potential those thoughts get brushed off quickly. You soon realize the most lucrative venture in which you can partake is arms dealing, not just to little girls but the whole town, and soon your business begins to grow. Rapidly. There are dungeons all around town to be plundered, and your little store is where all the locals can stock up on supplies to go butcher and conquest the local flora and fauna for the sake of your -- and your debtor's -- profits.

As you grow, you get some "regulars" who are willing to do some side jobs in the dungeons for you. One girl tries to rob you, but you convince her quickly, through a bit of gift and bribery, that she should instead steal for you. She agrees, and soon begins to deliver stolen goods to you which you buy low and sell high. You soon realize that, while it's fine and great to let the villagers piddle in the dungeons, some of them seem to have valuable stuff coming from the dark woods...so you ask some of the "regulars" to do a bit of grave robbing for you.

These regulars have deep and riveting backstories. One -- I believe her name was Nagi or Benke or something -- is dressed in traditional Japanese garb with a spear. As you go through the dungeons, she confronts a giant enemy crab which is clearly based on ancient Japanese history. You learn to flip the crab and attack its weak point for massive damage,  and soon haul its massive shell back as a trophy to be sold. The common folk don't seem to want this, though, so who can make use of it?

The answer quickly becomes apparent to you: Alouette, a blond-haired blue-eyed girl from a wealthy neighboring state, soon arrives and is willing to pay a high price for your wears. She begins to tell you also of her struggles with the ultra-national banking corporation, and how it is at deep-rooted financial war with her home nation. Before she can finish, an unexpected interloper appears: a dark-skinned red-eyed prince of demons named Griff, who swears the annihilation of your people is his destiny. He denounces your capitalist ways ways as evil, and despite Recette's heart-felt protests for peace and properity under which all your people might live together in harmony, Griff persists.

Your story soon branches out from mere arms-peddling and price-fixing of the local economy: you must now defend the existence of your people from destruction. With hired arm, you march into Griff's stronghold, slaughtering his minions and bringing the rest to heel. As you reach the top of the tower, you best Griff in brutal one-on-one combat, admiring his tenacity but also revealing to him why he lost: you had the power of the capitalist banking arm behind you, while he only had his conviction. Though he fights valiantly, Griff ultimately loses, upon which you provide him an ultimatum: die in irrelevancy, or come visit your store where you can teach him the truth of the world. Demonkind is broken and beaten, you remind him, but they do have a future.

Griff, to your surprise, shows up a few days later. While the fight with Griff was happening, Alouette's home nation falls to the international global banking conglomerate. Your debt has long since been repaid, but the reality has set in: Terme Financial Corporation, your debtor, isn't just after money -- they are after power. The debt you repaid them was not to simply grow a business, but conquest their enemies and establish a one-world bank upon which the President will rule as emperor. Alouette, in distress, disappears, and you strike out into the Lapis Ruins to search for her.

In a tear-jerking, penultimate climax, you send Griff into the depths of the Lapis Ruins to confront the President. Here it is revealed he has captured Alouette and her fairy, holding them as slaves, and only you can save them. His lust for power and insatiable greed has turned him into the form a giant demon, well in excess of what Griff was capable of conjuring himself. But now Griff is outfitted with your own weapons of war -- and trust me, you are indeed an arms broker to be feared the world around at this point. Hellclaw, Seventh Spike of Baphomet, wretched from the very fallen angel himself, now sits upon Griff's arms. With spite and rage, you turn Griff upon his real enemy, and only through violent combat do you financially strike down Terme Finance and rid the world of the President's ambition.

And this is where your journey ends. Alouette is saved, and though her country is broken and ruined by Terme Finance beyond repair, they have finally been expelled. It is once again her own country, and reconstruction can be begin. Meanwhile, you return to Reccetear with your own fairy, filling the void of Terme's collapse with your own financial dealings. At this point, you have at least 10x the amount of money you had paid in debt so many years -- er, days -- ago to your debtor. War is coming to the dungeons, you smile, and soon thoughts creep into your mind...what if you started your OWN banking corporation with the profits?

The possibilities are Endless. Your game is now complete, and Endless mode begins.

10/10 Capitalism, ho!

I enjoyed the game - just completed story mode, but I'm looking forward to digging into it more. 

About a week before I got this, I bought Moonlighter because the combination of item shop management and dungeon diving has really appealed to me lately, but that game - while fun, just falls too far short of its potential - so I thought I'd give Recettear a try. 

I admit I was cringing a bit as I purchased it 'cause I really don't like cutesy anime. And It did turn out to be too cute for my taste, but at least it's not puerile, and there's none of that shrill overemotional voice acting that's so common with this kind of thing. The music is pretty annoying, but at least there's an option to mute it. It also turned out to be much more of what I'd hoped Moonlighter would be. 

- Recettear offers the player far more options for managing their shop than Moonlighter.
- There's more stuff to sell in Recettear, and it's more interesting stuff than Moonlighter. 
- The inclusion of intermittent fads, and instances of supply and demand helps make shopkeeping engaging.
- A story mode, survival mode, and endless mode and multiple characters to adventure with makes things more interesting.
- There are a lot of hidden facets in this game: scenes in various parts of the city to look out for and a decently-sized cast of characters to get to know.

I could probably go on for a bit, but the one area I thought Recettear lags behind in is combat, but I'm not so sure of that just now. Granted, it's an older game, but even then I'm not convinced higher res games like Moonlighter handle combat all that much better. Combat in Recettear may be more basic and less flashy, but I don't think it's any more repetitive than newer games - maybe even less repetitive since players have the option of adventuring with different characters whose weapons, fighting style, and abilities force you to play a little differently, not to mention the random dungeon conditions that pop up now and again that help to change things up a bit.

Anyway, if you're interested in games like Moonlighter - a meld between storekeeping and dungeon diving, this is a great game to explore - especially whenever it's on sale. $19.99 might be a bit steep, but there may be enough game modes and enough depth to the game to possibly - POSSIBLY justify buying it even at full price.

Recettear feels like something you'd play as a kid (or even an adult!) on a Nintendo handheld. It's got all the same charm and smooth graphics that you'd expect to find on a Nintendo DS game. Imagine my surprise when I found out that not only is this game only on PC, but it's got Japanese indie developers as well. For how well made this game is, I couldn't believe it.

Recettear follows the story of a young girl, Recette, having to convert her home into an item shop to repay her missing father's debts. The debt collector, a fairy named Tear, agrees to help Recette accomplish this goal by giving her advice and help to get started. While there's not much more to the main story than that, there are some interesting side-stories and scenes with the adventurers and customers that help you get to know the minor characters and give you a sense of what the town is like. While there aren't many of these side stories in your first run through the game, there are plenty of opportunities to see all the extra side scenes once you complete the game and enter endless mode, where there's a lot more character development and story to unlock.

If I had to describe Recettear simply, it's a mix of a simuation game and a JRPG. It's part dungeon crawling and leveling up, but part strategizing on what you need to do daily, and how much money you'll be making every week to pay back debts. As a fan of both casual sim games and JRPGs, Recettear made for a very enjoyable experience all around. While more time is spent doing the sim side of the game, the JRPG side of the game still holds its own with some interesting boss fights in the dungeons, unique monsters and gear, plus a crafting and collection system. Once you get to endless mode, you can pick whichever side of the JRPG/sim cut you'd like; devoting all your time to running the store, strictly dungeon crawling, or both. I can confidently say that endless mode has way more content in it than the story does, and makes the few hours it takes to complete the story worth it to unlock everything else you can do.

You as the player are in charge of making sure Recette's item store thrives and she can pay her debts on time. To get stock you can either pay an adventurer to help you dungeon crawl and pick up loot, or play the market and buy items from surrounding stores during sales, then sell at your own store during price surges. The strategy behind deciding how to get your store's stock and when to sell is really well done, as you not only decide what the most profitable route to get stock is, but you also have to determine what haggling points your customers will accept or turn away. Other small store mechanics come into play later in the game, such as fufilling orders and recommending items to certain customers. The store aspect is really well done in all of its points.

My biggest problem with the mechanics or gameplay of Recettear that other people may find as a sore point the longer they play and discover is that the dungeon is not needed past the first week to win. It's the most profitable when you're making very little money in the first in-game week, but after that you don't need it at all, in fact it's probably the worst route to take if you want to make the most money. When I played I found myself favoring just buying from merchants, which made the gameplay a little more repetitive and dull but also was the most efficient way to keep up with the scaling debt prices. However, once you've beaten the game and get to endless mode a lot of this frees itself up, as you no longer have debts to contend with and can play however you like, beating the dungeons and leveling up adventurers like you would in a regular JRPG.

Anyone who enjoys casual games with minor strategy, or dungeon crawling JRPGs would really enjoy Recettear. It feels like one of those games I could see taking with me on a handheld and sinking hours upon hours into the endless mode, collecting all the gear and beating all the dungeons. If you enjoy sim-like games or small-scale JRPGs that allow you to play how you want, Recettear is a required addition to your play list.

I get that this keeps things interesting/challenging, but when I keep getting price decrease events that target the only items (in my case, metal and food items) I have to sell a few days back-to-back before my debt deadline...this is either really bad luck, or artifical difficulty.

This leaves you with 2 options: Game over, or reload a previous save where you will likely lose 1 1/2 to 2 hours of playtime. Overall, I'd give this game an 8.5/10.

Recettear is a game that starts off very strong. The characters are charming, and the plot is simple, you are a girl who inherited her father's debt and have no way to pay it off. So, as luck would have it, a fairy comes to help you pay off your debt in an epic adventure of... capitalism?! The concept of running an item store to serve RPG heroes feels unique in this age of gaming. The mechanics are simple, yet can be difficult to master. Just how much cash can you swindle out of that old man? How much of a discount can you get on that sword being sold to you? As the game goes on, you'll get a feel for each of the different areas of the game, your store, the market, the smith, the town center, and expeditions.

Expeditions?

That's right. If you thought that running a store was all there was to do, rejoice to know that there's proper dungeon crawling to mix up the gameplay. It doesn't feel out of place, as your adventurers go out to gather materials for the store that you can't buy at the market. Combat feels responsive, if a little stiff, exploration is that of classic room-based dungeons, and is a great addition to the game. Between the stress of needing enough cash to pay off portions of your debt each week, and the stress of risking death in a dungeon while carrying the goods that could get you the cash, the two sections of the game blend together well.

That is, if you choose to partake in the dungeon-crawling.

It is possible to play only via buying and selling in the town to pay off your debt. This requires luck and mastery of business to do, however. Even then, playing this way is not recommended due to the game's flaws.

So what are these flaws? The addition of expeditions is meant to break up the gameplay and add variety. Despite this, there comes a point when you'll want to go out exploring, but the time constraint of paying off your debt gets in the way. You only have a certain amount of time each day, and you can't earn money while you aren't running the store. It's a lot easier to buy from the market than it is to explore for merchandise. In my own experience with the game, I forewent expeditions for the entire final week just to raise enough cash to pay the final debt. The game became rather boring and formulaic at this point. Dialogue can also become quite repetitive, as there is little variance in the lines spoken by the main character, her assistant, and general customers. Luckily, there are some unique customers, but their dialogue tends to meet the same fate.

After beating the game, there was an endless mode where I no longer had to worry about the debt. I quite literally jumped for joy at the fact, since I was both stressed (in a good way) from the cash I needed to raise, and that I could go on regular expeditions without fear of failing. There is also a survival mode with a permanently increasing debt each week, to put your mercantile skills to the test. 

If you want an RPG with a unique twist, and love the prospect of being the merchant that overprices everything, this game is for you. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

TL;DR: Recettear has an original concept and oozes charm, but its backward mechanics and repetitive gameplay make it hard to recommend.

When Recettear was first released in English in 2010, it quickly garnered critical acclaim from various corners of the gaming community. Having finished it for the first time in 2018, I’m having a hard time recommending it.

First, the positives. Recettear has a pretty original concept going for it: you play as the owner of an item shop, a place where people in town go to purchases various items, from swords to pieces of candy. You are Recette, a girl who is forced into running the shop to pay off her missing father’s debt. The game plays out as a mix between a dungeon-crawler, a time-management game and even a bit like a visual novel. Recette is a pretty great protagonist, there’s plenty of funny moments, and the game just oozes charm.

That said, the game has plenty of problems. First and foremost: the games mechanics seem to be designed to work against itself. In one of the few tutorials the game offers you get introduced to one of the basic concepts of the game: haggling. What it doesn’t tell you is that there are mechanics working behind the scenes, invisible to the player, that actively discourage haggling. This undermines one of the core ideas of the game, and the player wouldn’t know without looking up guides online.

This can make the game unreasonably hard at times. In fact, the game seems like it was designed that way. You see, the game works with loops: should you at any point fail to pay your debt at the end of the week, the game starts from the beginning, but a lot of stats get carried over. I found it hard to complete the game without restarting at least once. Ultimately, this hurts the game quite a bit, because it only exacerbates one of the its biggest flaws: it’s repetitive.

During most of the game, you’ll mostly be doing either one of two things: selling stuff or crawling in a dungeon. Selling things is relatively simple. Once you get the basic idea down, you’ll be setting prices very quickly. The challenge disappears almost immediately, and it just becomes busywork.
The same can be said for the dungeons. Dungeons in this game are randomly generated, which is to say, it arranged a couple of perfectly square rooms in a certain order on a small grid. It’s impossible to imagine dungeons that are any more dull than the ones encountered here. Contained within are a (very) small selection of monsters, a (very) small selection of traps, treasure chests and the occasional boring boss fight. Combine this with the extremely basic combat, and it gets really tedious fast.

On top of that, the game has some technical issues. It only runs in 4:3, which is really weird for a 3D game first released in 2007. The max available resolution is 1280x960. I experienced many frame drops in the dungeons, even though the environments are some of the most geometrically simple I’ve ever seen in a game. Gamepad support is not the best, and there is no mouse support. The game constantly assaults you with voice quips that are so very annoying, but fortunately these can be turned off.

Surprise, surprise I like capitalism games. 

Games like the old Harvest Moon games and Stardew Valley float my boat. 

So, it isn’t shocking that an item shop game would also meet the craving. 

This game not only has the challenge of paying off your debts via buying things low and selling them high, but also social interactions, interior decoration of your store and dungeon crawler elements. 

The dungeon crawler doesn’t really require much strategy beyond bringing food to keep your HP up and having quality weapons. There is  variety in the monsters you face and what they drop varies. You can sell items outright or create fusions in order to add value to the items sold. 

The social elements in the game are entertaining as well. You get to know which customers will pay higher prices and which ones are horrible and whiney about how much you charge. Some of the in-game dialogue is pretty funny:
(Somebody go rescue this guys grandchild- he is clearly being starved to death)

Personally, I found this game pretty entertaining. There is a wide variety of items to buy and as your merchant level goes up the items you can buy increases as well. If you fail to raise the required amount of money you loop back to the beginning of the game (you keep your items, but not your gold though). Which makes the game even more entertaining as you don’t feel like you’ve lost just because you failed to save up 500,000 pix in your first or second loop. 

After you beat the game once you get the option of survival mode (where the game and payments get higher and higher) and endless play (where you can just play forever if you want and rack up ridiculous amount of money).

37904393.review:
[h1]The best Shop Management game I've ever played[/h1]

Don't let its somewhat dated visuals fool you, I've been looking several years for a worthy follow-up game and have yet to find one.

You play as [b]Recette[/b], a young girl living on her own, getting saddled with a massive loan taken out by her father according to [b]Tear[/b], a fairy that informed her about the bill.  She'll have to learn the ins-and-outs of shop management from Tear if she wants to manage the monthly payments which get bigger as the year passes.  As a shop management game primarily, you'll have to go with the old standby of trading [i]'Buy low and Sell high!'[/i] if you want to avoid defaulting on your payments!  It's set in a village which has an economy which fluctuates based on trends.  Sometimes prices of metal goods will rise, sometimes food prices will fall.  You can go around town and buy from the shops, or from people who come into your own shop when it's open for business.  Different shoppers have different preferences and some are stingier (or poorer) than others.

It also has [i]dungeon crawling[/i] for the purposes of obtaining loot without paying another shop or seller first.  You can obtain multiple people with different stats and abilities to dungeon delve with. and their equipment changes depending on what they've bought from you and what you've given them.  When exploring dungeons you control your companion, not Recette as she's a shop owner, not a warrior or mage.  It's not particularly in-depth, but it's definitely more than a minigame.  It's not necessary, beyond the tutorial in the plot, so if you prefer to rely on exploiting the market exclusively, you can do that.

[b]If only this game had a sequel[/b].  That's about the only negative thing I can say about it.

If I had to describe the overall vibe of Recettear it would be that it feels like Monster Rancher, but with more story and less grinding.

The story goes more in depth, but the basic premise is that your Dad mysteriously disappeared and you now have to pay his debts, so you open an item shop. Different types of customers (old man, merchant, various adventurers, other main characters, etc) come in to buy and sell items, and your job is to maximize profits and have enough for your debt payments at the end of each week which increase over time.

At a high level, the strategy is to figure out the pricing tolerance of customer types through experimentation and haggling and how they change as your reputation changes, hiring (and playing!) adventurers to go into dungeons to find crafting ingredients and rare items not available in the market, how variables affect short and long term sales, and balancing them in various situations.

This all starts off nice and simple, but as you progress increasingly complex variables are introduced. A couple of examples are managing the atmosphere (i.e. the "feel" of your shop) based on what items you place where and your decorations which attract different types of customers, and taking advantage of random events such as supply and demand changes and news broadcasts. Also as you progress, more things can happen other than just a customer buying/selling which makes the gameplay more interesting. Playing as the adventurer and going through dungeons is also fun.

Overall I like it a lot. There's enough complexity to make it interesting and it does a good job of simulating a real market, but not so complex that it's overwheliming. Once you're a few hours into the game, I'd recommend keeping a pad of paper and pencil handy. It's not necessary, but sometimes it's nice to be able to track what items you've bought really cheap that you want to push more, things like that.

36160124.review:
Recettear is a game where you play a young girl whose dad left her with a massive (not actually, if you keep a tally) debt and a tiny French fairy arrives to collect it. They come up with a payment plan and set up an item shop. Sounds boring, doesn't it?

Well, IT REALLY IS NOT! There's a surprising amount of things you can do in this game. You can (and should) customize your shop to attract different types of customer, e.g. young girls won't enter a store that looks like it does blood sacrifice on Sundays. You have 4 ways to get items: The market, where you can buy consumables, treasures, clothing, decorations and books. The Merchant Guild, where you can buy combat gear. Buying random items from customers once you reach a certain Merchant Level. Going into a dungeon and picking up drops. Each day is split into 4 time slots and the customers that you can get (and their quantity) varies based on the time, so for example you're not going to see young girls shopping in the evening.

The dungeons have an entire plot of their own, where you'll meet various characters and they'll become customers for your store or a customer for your store turns out to be an adventurer. You don't HAVE TO go into the dungeons, but the dungeons are the only place to drop items used for Fusion, which is basically a crafting system where you can create new items or more powerful versions of existing ones. The different adventurers that you unlock are all different, with single target or area-of-effect attacks, low or high HP/SP, ranged or melee attacks, different kind of special attacks or just... moving really fast. The game tells you that the dungeons are a good way to get stuff for your store, as you pay nothing for the drops. This is true, and you can find a lot of goodies in there, but it also takes a hella lot of time: Just going into the dungeon takes half of an entire day and exploring can take a lot in terms of real playtime.

The actual selling of items is surprisingly complex, with an experience system where you get experience based on how well you did with the haggling. The Merchant Levels will unlock store upgrades and give you access to more expensive items in the Market and Merchant Guild. Every type of customer has a different way they'll haggle. Some have very little money, so even if you give them a huge discount, they still won't buy stuff. Others are the opposite. Some will haggle based on the percentage of profit you try to make. Later on, items can become scarse or abundant based on how much you sell them. Also randomly, a specific item or item type will become "popular" with a type of character: You can use this to summon a literal horde of customers that will only buy that specific thing from you.

Once you clear the game, you unlock Infinite mode, where you can just keep doing things forever. You also unlock a mode where the debt will keep rising indefinitely as long as you keep paying it.

The characters in Recettear are also quite something. The main character, Recette is a dim, happy-go-lucky little girl who somehow forgot that it's been literally weeks since she last saw her father. Tear is a fairy sent to collect the money Recette's dad owns and she's all business, all the time. Bonus points for French swearing. Louie is the first adventurer you meet and he's a young, hopeful kid who is always poor. Caillou is a young wizard who simply will not accept that Recette owns the shop. Charme is a thief that really likes getting drunk and trying to sell you overpriced items. Alouette is your self-proclaimed rival and eventual heiress to the largest chain store around, who is accompanied by a fairy of her own.

If there is something negative about Recettear, it's that it's too damn positive. You're neck deep in debt, you have like 800 pix to your name, which buys you like one bowl of food and your father is missing. Meanwhile, the in-game music is stupidly chipper and catchy. You are supposed to be in a desperate situation, with a literal loan shark LIVING WITH YOU AND WATCHING YOUR EVERY MOVE... and yet your biggest worry is when a little girl won't pay 800 pix for a sandwich because THEIR ALLOWANCE IS LIKE 300 PIX OR SOMETHING!

Recettear is not a game you play for the story: There really isn't much of a story or a "real" ending. Recettear is a game you play to explore the possibilities that the game gives you. Become a merchant that only sells 3 expensive weapons because that's all you can buy. Become a merchant who only sells one type of item (and perish because you can't feed a starving young man a book). Become an adventurer who only sells +11 Slime. Become an order-only merchant, only stocking items that people have ordered from you. Become a hoarder, making sure that you always have several of any given item type available. Just... do whatever, it all works. More or less. And hey, if you fail, you'll just lose all of your cash and start from the beginning.

34598367.review:
There are some idiotic negative reviews for this game. People saying it's too difficult to learn or the controls are horrible or whatever. Maybe those things are true if you're an idiot, but for anybody with 1/2 a brain, the controls are easy to learn & most of the gameplay is also. I always check the keybinds of any new game I play to see what you can do, but there were only a couple buttons I didn't figure out before I checked the keybinds. As I said, very easy controls. As for the gameplay, the game teaches you what you need to know to do alright. The dungeon aspect is very easy to learn, like most top-down action style games. The merchant aspect is a bit more complex, but not much. The most difficult thing to learn in this game is the best price-percent to sell/buy at with each customer. You have 2 ways to do this: 1- Old-school style, where you note every percent you try to buy/sell at with each customer & whether it worked until you find the best percentage for each, or 2- Wiki style, where you simply Google it & use the wiki to read the same information you could easily figure out on your own. Again, not exactly difficult either way, it would merely take longer to figure out if you do it old-school. I initially did things old-school, then decided using the wiki would simply speed up the game some without really cheating because it wouldn't give me any info I couldn't, or wouldn't eventually, get myself in-game.

The biggest down-side to the game? When you sell things in merchant mode, it doesn't pull the items from your stock, it pulls them from the display. In other words, you must put something on display to sell it (or in a vending machine). If you have 5 of the item in stock, the item you put on display is still the item sold instead of using your stock, forcing you to replace every display item you sell before each merchant session & preventing the same item being sold to 2 different customers each session (assuming you have multiple in stock to sell to multiple customers) unless you place multiple copies of it. It isn't exactly difficult to replace the items, it simply takes time. That's the only bad part of this game, and it isn't exactly horrible. It would be much better if they made it so it pulled from stock, but it would only save you a little time & hassle, nothing more.

The rest of the game is very fun & cute. It isn't the most action-oriented gameplay ever, nor is it the most fun game I ever played, but it is fun, easy to learn, & has a cute story with cute graphics. It requires multiple play-throughs to unlock everything, but so what? Each playthrough can be endless until you decide to end it, each restart has the potential to unlock new things depending on how you did things this time through, and dying or failing at worst forces you to restart through New Game + so you don't lose everything.

Is it worth $20? Well, I have 100 hours played so far and will be playing more, so technically yes, especially if you don't mind the potentially repetitive item placing for the merchant system. However, if you can get it for $10 or less, definitely worth grabbing.

Ridiculously fun!

I'm a fan of roguelikes and their cousins. I'm also a fan of games in which you actually use the resources gained in your journeys to do something, rather than just progress. One of my favorite games on Playstation was Azure Dreams, for example. And now, in PC gaming, there is Recettear.

Recettear is the story of a girl who inherits an item store... and a debt to go along with it. In order to pay off your debt, you need to sell things. In order to sell things, you need to get things. In order to get things, you need to buy things. In order to buy things, you need money. In order to get money, you need to sell things. 

"Capitalism, ho!"

So where does my discussion about the 'Roguelike' come in? Well, among the many things you can sell, most of the better ones, as well as a variety of combination ingredients (because like almost all my favorite games, this game has a crafting system of some sort!) are in the dungeons of the game, which are ever-evolving. In fact, if you progress far enough, you will find that the dungeon evolution is an actual *part of the game's storyline*.... but I digress. For your average player, this makes it an endless cycle of getting items, pricing items, selling items, returning to the dungeon, et cetera. 

Multiple adventuter characters show up in the game, each with an actual backstory to them. A story that one may have to dig deep to find, or go to certain locations at certain times, but that all exist to some degree or another. It just adds another layer of depth to a game that could be dull if done wrong.... but 'Wrong' is definitely not the case with this game, if my playtime doesn't say that loudly enough. 

I have a mental wishlist of what I would like in my perfect game. Recettear ticks better than 3/4 of those boxes, and adds its own spin on them. To that end, I honestly can't recommend it highly enough for people like me who enjoy 'roguelikes with a purpose', particularly when they include good characters and a few mysteries and hidden secrets to go along with them, not to mention after-campaign challenges and reasons to keep playing even *after* you have 'finished' the game! 

There may be a day when I finally get everything, and get completely bored with the game. However, I can safely say that this is not that day. Tomorrow ain't looking good, either.

Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale follows Recette and Tear (hence Recettear) on their epic quest of... running an Item shop to pay back debts.

What may sound boring is actually a great game. The item shop system is well designed, the characters are funny and the dungeons are... dungeons, I guess. It should also be mentioned that the game's story is told in passages like a visual novel, while dungeons and the shop are played with the sprites of the according characters.

First of all, let's look at the item shop itself. To even have items for sale, you need to buy them first from merchants or find them in dungeons. Some items can only be found in dungeons, others can only be crafted with ingredients found in dungeons. Those items may be valuable, however, they are not essential for winning the game.

To sell items, you have to place them around your shop. Location is key, items placed at the windows will attract customers and have a higher chance of being bought. Furthermore, some items may become more expensive or cheaper for a short duration, so you have to adjust your prices and locations accordingly.

Not every customer will simply buy everything at any price, they will try to haggle to either sell their item higher or buy yours cheaper. Depending on the current values of items, you may even offend customers, causing them to leave. Succesfully selling items will grant experience which is crucial in expanding your shop. In addition, not every customer likes every atmosphere. Little girls like bright shops while thieves and assassins like it a bit more sinister. Using decorations allows you to change the atmosphere of your shop, either attracting or repelling specific customers. Combine this with higher prices for highly demanded items to become rich very quickly.

As for the characters, they are almost all likeable. Most of them have some quirks which lead to funny dialogues or situational comedy, but often it's just Recettes comments that made me laugh. Phrases such as "Holy carp!"[NOT a typo] make the novel part of the game so enjoyable.

The dungeons are nothing special, randomly generated and filled with different monsters with different colours. To enter a dungeon, you'll have to recruit an adventurer first and actually pay them to work for you. Furthermore, going to a dungeon will take more time than running your shop, so I highly suggest you play through the dungeons on your NewGame+.

The graphics are not great, honestly speaking. While characters are well designed, the overall game is not an artistic masterpiece. The music is great, though. The qatchy themes made me stop playing just to listen to the music.

All in all, Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a solid game with a few flaws, but tons of fun. I often wanted to play "just five more minutes" and ended up closing the game two hours later. It is a good game and worth it's money, but try to get it on sale, simply because: Capitalism, ho!

As for sound, the music is simple but cute. All the written text has been translated to English, though, so it’s completely playable–also, the translation is actually quite good. 32052009.review: Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a game where you play as a young entrepreneur with immense monetary-related debt to a magical loan shark. The object of the game is to make enough money to meet each week's deadline and pay off the ever increasing amount. Despite this, Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a genuinely fun, cute, and surprisingly relaxing game. The game is split up into two core mechanics, shop management and dungeon crawling. The first being exactly what it sounds like. You decorate your shop, place items in key locations to attract customers, take orders, stock up on items, pay attention to item related trends, haggle, and BUY LOW AND SELL HIGH! The dungeoneering aspect revolves around your partnerships with a couple adventurers whom you control in the dungeons, going through levels in order to obtain loot to sell in your shop. There are 4 periods in a day: Morning, Noon, Evening, and Night. Certain places are only open on certain hours or on certain days. Due to how long it takes (2 periods), visiting the dungeon can only viably be done in the mornings. Due to this mechanic, I felt it necessary to start the game over once or twice because about 3 weeks in, I began to have trouble putting together the amount needed each week. It was only after consulting the wiki and guides that I was able to figure out how to spend each day wisely. Overall it's a very fun game. I would recommend tweaking the controls to your liking if you're playing with a keyboard as the game uses the default japanese layout for it's controls, or just play with a controller (that's the method I prefer).

32029921.review: This is a very fun and addictive game. However, if you don't have the right strategy it can become an extremely frustrating game. First, save a lot. Second, pay attention to announcements. When item prices go up, you can sell those particular items for up to 300% profit! When item prices go down, buy them cheap from the merchants - stock up! If you are going dungeoneering, enter the dungeon first thing in the morning because that takes 2 our of 4 time slots to complete. **Remember to spend your time slots wisely** Have at least 2 of each item-type because you never know when a customer will want them. Get to know your customers and the amount they can pay. To increase your merchant level faster, which is the most important thing to do besides making money, you will want to sell on the first try with back to back customers. Not only does that increase your level faster, it also makes the customers happy. Purchase different types of decor for your space as you will need to modify it to increase the number of customers who stop by to shop. Always ask Tear about the status of the shop's decor before you open your doors. On her grid, you want to be at the center. When certain items are in demand you can sell them for from 200-300% profit, depending on the customer. Finally, place the items you want to sell most by the North-facing windows. As your merchant level goes up, you will unlock new things. Take advantage when you can pay the weaponsmith to increase the size of your shop. I won the main game without purchasing Vending Machines. Not sure if they are a good investment. Is the game worth $19.99? Maybe, if you love haggling like a merchant, Japanese-style games with cute art and dialogue, crafting and making money. 31061236.review:
Bought the game when it was on sale
CAPITALISM, HO!

You may be thinking to yourself: "Is this game as simple and bare as it looks on the screenshots?" It's a not a bad question. At first glance, Recettear looks like a rather dated game centered around the niche topic of running an item shop in medieval-style world. Characters are 2-D sprites in a 3-D game world that would look at home on a PS1, and dungeon crawling is a simple hack-and-slash with different unlockable adventurers bringing a different class and playstyle to the table. While the game is hardly complicated or difficult, it is definitely charming and captivating. However, it is so much more than that, and the game really impressed me with it's hidden depths.

To shorten things a bit, the core game and plot is about Recette, a little girl whose missing father has a large unpaid loan about to default. In order to not lose her home, Recette, with the help a 'loan-shark' fairy named Tear, open an item store and begin trading in order to make enough money to make the weekly loan repayment. As you might expect, as the weeks pass, the amount required to pay grows exponentially until you either fail or manage to make the final payment. The main plot spans about 5 ingame weeks, and should you fail to make a payment, you start a new 'loop' from Day 2 with every item you owned as well as whatever cash you had left - this greatly helps remove the frustration of having to start all over from scratch.

So you might think that this is an easy game to beat. Well, yes, but the real meat and potatoes comes from post-game content. Beating the main game unlocks Endless mode, where you simply continue running the item shop with no more loans to pay back; New Game+, which starts a new loop with money and items carried over; and Survival mode, which has never ending weekly loan payments that grow until they overwhelm you.

Is there a point in continuing your save free from debt? Hell yes there is. You see, the core game with its dungeon feature only barely scratch the surface of the content and characters the game has to offer. Within the first in game month, you are highly unlikely to meet even half of the available adventurers you can hire, unlock all dungeons, or even make a dent in the item encyclopaedia. In fact, there is essentially a post-game questline to still follow through to the end!

Considering that I expected the game to be focused on that one lone month of paying bills, I was impressed with how polished the gameplay mechanics are, and pleasantly surprised by the amount of content this game has that adds to replayability. For how the game looks to the average person viewing the store page, this game is diamond in the rough, and I wholly recommend it if you want a light-hearted game to drop hours into
