30587639.review:
It's a great little game, emphasis on little.

In no particular order, here are a few things to note:

[list]
[*][b]Visuals:[/b]
[list]
[*]The illustrations leave a lot to be desired, but the sprites are lively and cute.
[*]Like many small games, Recettear uses 2D sprites on ugly 3D backgrounds when you're in combat (which is a LOT).
[*]There are only four customers. Sometimes, a lot of the same one will show up... and it's kinda creepy.
[*]Enemy designs are also limited. Most are just palette swaps of the first dungeon's enemies.
[*]The HUD is clean & easy to navigate. It could use some polish, but it's fine as it is.
[*]It offers windowed & fullscreen.
[/list]

[*][b]Music:[/b]
[list]
[*]The shop's theme is pleasantly happy.
[*]You'll get tired of the looping dungeon music... but it's nothing that bad.
[*]The game has full volume control. You can mute effects and music independently.
[/list]

[*][b]Story:[/b]
[list]
[*]By far, the worst part of the game. Characters are flat, one-dimensional and generally boring. So, don't be expecting some Harvest Moon-style relationships to develop.
[*]Each companion has a miniature story that's revealed through events.
[*]This is not a RPG, its story is extremely short and it resets to the beginning once you pay off your loan.
[*]Due to the reset, you'll often see a character's first event several times before you see their second, simply because you weren't focusing on their story in your previous playthroughs. Events ARE skippable, though, so don't panic.
[*]The dialogue often strains to be funny, but just sounds dumb. There are a lot of flat jokes, clumsy references, etc.
[/list]

[*][b]Gameplay[/b]
[list]
[*]Recettear uses a mix of time management and dungeon crawling that's like a very stripped down version of Persona 3.
[*]This not a shop simulator. It's a dungeon crawler with a shop mini-game. You will need to spend a LOT of time in the dungeons.
[*]Combat is really simple. Companions have only one normal attack and a few, often useless, special attacks that consume mana. It's boring and mindless, but sometimes that's what you want in a game.
[*]The shop mini-game is fun and relaxing. You can change the shop's look, put items on display and haggle over the prices.
[*]Unfortunately, haggling is pointless (and the game penalizes you for doing it). Since all generic customers have one of four fixed budget ranges, you'll quickly find the "sweet spot" for prices and stick with it.
[/list]

[*][b]Spoiler-free Tips:[/b]
[list]
[*]Remember to visit the blacksmith. He'll eventually offer item crafting and shop expansions.
[*]Items that you're buying will still show the "Price Up" and "Price Down" colors (red & blue). Don't be fooled, you're the only merchant these matter to. The blacksmith & wholesaler will still charge the normal price. This means you can buy a bunch of hot items and turn them for massive profits. (Assuming you don't overbuy!)
[*]The "mood" of the store's decorations affects which companions show up to shop.
[*]Customers start with small budgets. It is absolutely essential that you increase them by buying/selling items WITHOUT haggling and at prices within their "sweet spot". If you don't do this, they won't be able to afford the more expensive items... and you'll be screwed.
[*]Don't neglect your Merchant Level. Raising it is how you unlock crafting recipes and store expansions. Your Merchant Level increases the same way customers' budgets do... so that's one more reason to NOT haggle and make sure you hit that sweet spot.
[*]In case it wasn't obvious, the "Near" and "Just" bonuses that you see after transactions are indications that your price was in the sweet spot. (i.e. near it, on it)
[/list]
[/list]

All told, it's a simple game that offers simple joys. People who like grinding for crafting ingredients will enjoy Recettear, since that's by far the largest part of it. The rest of us can also find some fun redecorating the shop and playing the mini-game. Get it on sale, if you're interested.

Oh, and I strongly recommend newcomers google a guide on making money. The game is short and the loan payments ramp up VERY fast. For those who don't want to "cheat", let me just say reselling [spoiler]sweets (Watermelon, Takiyaki)[/spoiler] is a good starting point and [spoiler]Mermaid Shoes (Level 1 Shoes)[/spoiler] are very profitable once you unlock item crafting. They're made of [spoiler]Leather Boots (from the Wholesaler) + Water Crystal (dropped by black knights)[/spoiler].

30565208.review:
This will be a fairly detailed review--the gist of it is that this is an extremely well polished game whose core mechanics--which is managing your item shop--are splendidly executed and introduced to the player smoothly, but this is all rounded out by the charming and endearing--optional--story, as you meet and interact with the townsfolk around the area. The characters are likeable and you learn more about them as you take more time out of the day to explore the city. It's almost like Final Fantasy 6 in the second half of the game.

All I can say is--this game is amazing. Honestly--the best way I can describe this game is a item shop tycoon/dungeon crawler/visual novel, all jumbled into one game. And yes, I said visual novel, which I will get into later.

So the primary premise of this game is that you run an item shop on a day to day basis, kind of like a Diner Dash-esque sort of game. From start to finish, the primary goal of the game is to make enough money to pay off your debt in weekly installments. That might seem boring, but in actuality the plethora of options that are given to you at every given moment make the game so much more than an item shop tycoon game, and it makes for such a fun and unique experience.

Regarding the item shop tycoon aspect of the game--it is spectacularly done. There is just so much that goes into managing your shop, that it just feels fresh while you progress through the game. What do you decide to put in front of your window, which will affect what kind and how many customers will come in? Should you decide to invest in expanding your shop? Should you buy vending machines for your shop, which allow for increased and automated sales at the expense of customer interaction?

But I think the absolute best thing they did with this game is the PROGRESSION that you learn all these things. Sooner or later, as you start to buy and sell more things, and decide what to do with your shop, you start to distinguish between the different kinds of customers that want to buy things. There is simply a consistent pattern--this kind of customer just won't pay that much for an item (and you will learn to hate those customers), and maybe this other kind of customer has a bit of coin left in their pocket, so you can maybe offer him a higher price. It's all very subtle and unstated, but learned by the player as you sell more items. It's honestly magical.

And what will be your main strategy to earn your keep? Should you go buy from the market and take advantage of item booms and lows? Or go dungeoneering into the depths to procure items and sell for 100% profit? Should you choose to go dungeoneering, you will learn that it's a very difficult balancing act of opportunity cost. Should I keep this item, or toss it to pick up this one? Should I use this healing item, or risk killing mobs to wait until I level up, which will heal me fully? Should I progress through the dungeon to use the day more efficiently, or not take the risk and use the checkpoint to go back home?

The day is divided into four slices. For each slice, you can choose to open your shop, go to the market, explore the city, or go dungeoneering, all consuming a certain number of slices. However, should you choose to go to the market, exploring the city will not take up any additional time. It's an ingenious way to make the player able to enjoy the story-side of the game. When you explore the city, you will interact with the townsfolk, which will bring up a short scene with your characters and their friends. As you take the time to explore the city more and more, you realize that each character has a backstory to them, and they develop more and more. It's one of the things I enjoyed most about this game.

The only gripe that I may have about this game is that the dungeoneering is actually very difficult. The controls are tight and fair, but some of the bosses spike in difficulty and you may easily die if you are not prepared for them. Dying in a dungeon renders your day obsolete, and all the time and effort you put in getting up to that point.

While I love all forms of gaming, Visual novels don't rank very high with me. I find them to be a linear experience and pretty much akin to reading a comic book with less panels. It's a genre that for me to really enjoy, it needs to have something extra thrown into the mix. War of the Human Tanks had a strategy aspect to it. Loren the Amazon Princess was a turn based RPG.

Which brings me to Recettear, This game has been on my radar for many years but I was always afraid to make the plunge but Steam sales being what they are, here I am twenty hours later and I loved every minute of it. Recettear takes the style of visual novels for its storytelling and throws in shop management and an extremely in depth dungeon diving/crafting system.

The games story is rather simple, one day a fairy named Tear shows up at your door.(Hence RecetTEAR) She explains that your father has disappeared/passed away and now all his debts have fallen to his daughter, Recette. Our main character is daft as a bird so Tear decides to help her run an  item shop so she can pay back her debt. Spoilers! You owe close to a million bucks in debt and have a month to pay it! Capitalism, Ho!

You will have to buy low, sell high, bargain, and pinch every single penny to be able to make all the payments in time. While it seems daunting the game gives you plenty of opportunity if you're smart.

Recettear is a cute game. When I say cute, I mean this is bubblegum and rainbows type of visuals, story, and mechanics. If you happen to be a fan of anime you're going to be right at home here, but those who are unfamiliar with the style may be thrown off by it. Just expect giant cute googly eyes , fairies, and plenty of over the top emoting. Obviously the game has an anime aesthetic when it comes to character design so I am not going to talk about that all that much. It's a 'you like it or don't' type of scenario. I thought the characters were well designed but general run of the mill fantasy anime stereotypes. Where things completely change is in the dungeons and shop management.

One very important thing to note is that the game is not in a 16:9 resolution. This like most other Japanese visual novels comes in a 4:3 aspect ratio.

Shop management is done in an over the top view where you can control our main character, Recette. The game really reminds me of Paper Mario where you are a flat RPG sprite running around 3d environments. Its really well done and gives the entire game a dynamic feeling. Your shop is your bread and butter. You will spend about half the game there. You can re-design your shop, re-arrange just about everything and place items to sell.

There is an atmosphere system that depending on how your store looks will attract certain customers. Lean towards gaudy and expect a couple shady people, design in heretical tones and maybe a demon might show up. It's something I really thought was great and wish it had been expanded upon more. There are only about two dozen people in the game to sell too. So don't expect it to get that deep sadly.

If you are a wise shop-keeper, the best idea is to get something for nothing and sell it at a high price. Enter the Adventurers guild where you can hire a character you've befriended and go into dungeons for rare treasure. This aspect to the game is almost in itself a whole other game. This is where that Paper Mario aspect really kicks in, except Recettear is all about real time combat. Which can lead to some moments where your depth perception is going to be thrown off. It's not a huge deal but it happens frustratingly.

You run around randomly generated environments battling monsters, bosses, and avoiding traps. There are a total of eight unique heroes that you meet throughout the story and some you can access playing in the games Endless mode. Heroes all have their own unique equipment, abilities, and different fighting styles which is amazing. The adventurers all buy their equipment from your shop, so its up to you to equip them properly. You can let them "borrow" items for a dungeon delve but that takes up valuable inventory space for treasure. Level progress is done in a survival of four levels and then a boss level, you have to option to leave at that point or move on for another five levels.

The entire dungeon system is really awesome and for the first part of the game is super useful. Things start to fall apart though nearing the final weeks of the Story mode. Most of the treasure in the first 3 dungeons don't scale up with the amount of money that you need to pay your debt. By the time you get to the final week where you owe 500k, you are hopefully dealing in sales around 20-70k per transaction. Where dungeon loot maxes out at 1-10k. The reason being, is that the developer wanted the end game content to be all about that shiny treasure you find and give you a reason to come back. Once you complete the initial story mode, additional dungeons are available that have upwards of 500k type of treasure. I understand to control balance, why this was done, but it doesn't make dungeon diving a rewarding experience in the later half of story mode.

As you progress through the weeks, you earn merchant levels that give you access to more crafting recipes, more customization options, and store expansions which allow you to put up more for sale. You earn merchant levels through successfully haggling with your customers. It's a rather awesome system and feels super rewarding when you sell that big ticket item you wanted. There are market fluctuations, trends, and people who will want to sell items to you. These market fluctuations are a BIG deal and the key to beating the game. Buy low, sell high.

People selling you items is my BIGGEST gripe with this game. Imagine dealing with hundreds thousands of pix(gold) and selling antiques, magic weapons and armor and then suddenly someone wants to sell you a lottery ticket and haggle over the price. This happens quite often and by the end of the game If I bought one more dang cherry I was going to lose my mind. While customers gain more of a gold pool through successful interactions and earn trust levels. It would seem that the item pool that they draw from doesn't ever upgrade. Keep in mind, this is solely based off my experience in Story mode.

Aside from the minor gripes mentioned, Recettear is a fun and enjoyable game. It never gets dull to set up your shop just the way you want it and make oodles of money. Dungeon diving, while not super rewarding near the end, is far more complex and extends well beyond the end of the game. The item encyclopedia is robust and you could probably triple my game time trying to fill it out completely. Additionally from the Endless mode, you have New Game+ mode which is more or less the same experience except you keep all items, levels, etc. There is also a survival mode where the amount of money required to pay your bill keeps rising until you can't keep up.

The game features controller support, delightful voice work and a jaunty little soundtrack that matches the tone of the game very well. The game doesn't have steam cards or achievements which is kind of a bummer. I can only assume this has to do with Recettear being translated for an English audience and not the other way around.

As mentioned earlier, I got about twenty hours purely out of story mode. The game has amazing replayability if you enjoy its mechanics. I got the game on sale for $2.99 which made the game worth it and more then I could have ever hoped. I still think the game is worth it even if you can't nab it on sale though. It's not a perfect game but its unique and innovative and mixes genres very well. I couldn't stop playing the game from beginning to end and there is still more to do to the games credit.

If you are in the market for a visual novel but want to stray off the beaten path, Recettear is an easy choice. It's bug free and really well made.

28990003.review:
If you have played Moonlighter before, then this game may come off familiar to you.

Main objective of the game is to pay off a debt your father left behind within a month, and you can accomplish that by selling items in your Item Shop. 

There are many ways to acquire these items, you can play at it like a dungeon crawler where you hire adventurers to conquer rogue-like dungeons and bring back items for you to sell, or to buy and resell items from the local blacksmith, marketplace, or customers who offer to sell you items. 

The main plot doesn't last too long, as you only need to pay back the  debt by the end of the first month, but there is plenty to do in the post-game. Each adventurer you can hire has a form of a story to tell, and you can unlock dialogue and events in the dungeons by exploring them.

The adventurers also have different play-styles, which you can unlock as you progress further through the plot and dungeons. Some adventurers, dungeon events, dungeons, map interactions, and shop interactions can only be unlocked in the post-game, which I would suggest playing all the way through. 

When I first played this game, I thought it would just be another anime game, however there is a surprising amount of content in this game. If you think the price-tag is too high however, you can wait for a sale as this game can go on sale for under 5$. Well worth the purchase and has replay-ability.
